column5: The shuttle Discovery triumphantly launches the Hubble Space Telescope.
column6: Two weeks after an aborted first try, the shuttle Discovery roared from Cape Canaveral into orbit 380 statute miles above earth.  There it successfully released the $1.5 billion dollar Hubble Space Telescope from its cargo bay.  Now in the process of overcoming some start-up problems, the telescope should soon be operational.
column7: The shuttle Discovery soared into space to launch its history-making payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.  While orbiting at 380 statute miles above Earth, it will provide astronomers worldwide with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  The telescope's release from the shuttle Discovery was delayed because a solar power panel took three tries before it fully unfurled.  Once released, ground controllers were unable to link up the telescope's two high-gain antennas with their assigned relay satellite.  However, scientists, optimistic that the Hubble will soon be operational, authorized the shuttle Discovery crew to return home.
column8: Following an aborted first try, the shuttle Discovery soared into space to launch its history-making payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.  Named after the American astronomer Edwin Hubble who did pioneering work leading to the "Big Bang" concept of the universe, it is NASA's most expensive spacecraft.  While orbiting at 380 statute miles above Earth during its expected 15-year working lifetime, it will provide astronomers world-wide with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories.  Free of Earth's distorting atmosphere, it may be able to look back almost to the beginning of time.  The telescope's release from the shuttle Discovery came two hours and one orbit later than planned.  A troublesome solar power panel took three tries before it fully unfurled, causing the delay.  Two Mission Specialists astronauts were standing-by to unfurl the panel manually if necessary.  Then more start-up problems, ground controllers were unable to link up the telescope's two high-gain antennas with their assigned relay satellite.  A weaker back-up antenna system is working.  The telescope was placed on special flight modes until these start-up problems are resolved.  Confident that the Hubble will soon be operational, the shuttle Discovery is preparing to return home.
column9: Discovery carries $1.5 billion Hubble Telescope to space April 24, 1990
column10: On April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the Hubble Space Telescope 380 miles into space, then followed briefly to assist if necessary. In orbit above Earth's distorting atmosphere for 15 years, Hubble would see 10 times better than Earth telescopes. Hubble's launch had been delayed since 1983. Hubble cost $1.5 billion.
column11: On April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the 12.5-ton Hubble SpaceTelescope 380 miles into space. Orbiting above Earth's distortingatmosphere, Hubble would see 10 times better than the largest Earthtelescopes. Technical problems exacerbated by conservative systemsettings put Hubble several days behind schedule. Discovery's fiveastronauts were all veterans of previous flights. Discovery followedHubble for two days to assist if necessary. Spacelab Astro was to beput up two weeks later to give additional target information. Hubblecost $1.5 billion, with millions more projected for support over its15-year lifetime. Discovery carried a telescope eyepiece used by EdwinHubble, for whom the Hubble is named.
column12: On Tuesday, April 24, 1990, shuttle Discovery carried the 12.5-ton Hubble Space Telescope 380 miles into space. Once in orbit above Earth's distorting atmosphere, Hubble would be able to see 10 times better than the largest Earth telescopes. Wednesday it was lifted into space by Discovery's mechanical arm and released into orbit. Friday the 94.5-inch mirror was exposed to starlight. Saturday controllers took Hubble out of safe mode. Problems with a solar power array, communications antennas, and two position-stabilizing gyroscopes -- exacerbated by conservative limits set on systems -- put Hubble several days behind schedule and delayed transmittal of the first photograph. Discovery's astronauts -- Shriver, Bolden, Hawley, McCandless, and Sullivan - - were all veterans of previous flights. The shuttle followed Hubble for two days to assist if necessary. A seven-month checkout period would follow. Spacelab Astro was to be put up two weeks later to give Hubble additional target information. Hubble, delayed since 1983, cost $1.5 billion. Spare parts, training, and software cost $500 million more. Maintenance cost $7 million a month on Earth and will cost $200 million yearly in orbit, for Hubble's 15-year lifetime.  Discovery carried the Hooker Telescope eyepiece used by astronomer Edwin Hubble, for whom the Hubble is named.

column3: INDIA suffered fresh wave terror last night when explosion destroyed two blocks flats centre city Calcutta, killing least 45 people and injuring scores others. Police said bomb exploded crowded trade and residential district Bowbazaar shortly midnight, causing two blocks flats collapse and trapping 70 people rubble. The identity bombers was unknown explosion comes just five days 250 people were killed and least 1,200 injured series bomb attacks aimed heart Indian business capital Bombay. A militant Sikh group fighting independence Indian state Punjab has claimed responsibility Bombay blasts, police are unconvinced, saying they were carried out foreign group connivance 'local criminals'. In what many interpreted reference Pakistan, whom India has fought three wars, last week Mr Shankarrao Chavan, federal home (interior) minister, told parliament New Delhi that he suspected 'an international conspiracy.' Most estimated 125 people living Calcutta flats were their beds when blast occurred, setting fire buildings, according officials city's central control room. At least 45 people were dead arrival hospital, they said. Last Friday series car bombs exploded Bombay what government described systematic attack India's commercial heart. Among targets were Bombay Stock Exchange, landmark Air India building, shopping complex, and two hotels airport. The attacks Calcutta and Bombay are severe setback attempts heal wounds created recent intercommunal violence, which has caused deep shock throughout India. More 2,000 people died riots, including 700 Bombay, razing mosque Ayodhya northern India Hindu zealots December 6. Some fear wave bomb attacks is designed stir renewal communal strife and undermine efforts government Mr P V Narasimha Rao open economy and attract foreign investment and tourism. Last night national and local state leaders appealed calm attempt prevent renewed outbreak violence. Mr Rao urged nation ignore rumours 'inhuman and criminal blast'. A ROW has erupted Bombay stock exchange, India's largest stock market, and Securities and Exchange Board India, securities watchdog, board's recent first-ever inspection stockbrokers' books. The Sebi has accused stockbrokers flouting exchange's rules, including regulations margin trading designed limit risk members defaulting excessive speculative investments. It has also accused exchange authorities failing enforce rules and poor administration. The stock exchange denied allegations, saying they were 'baseless, made out context and blown out proportion.' The argument will do nothing restore investors' faith stock market where, measured Bombay stock exchange's 30-share index, shares have fallen 48 cent their peak early last year, including 320 points fall government's budget was announced two weeks ago. Yesterday index closed 2330. Foreign investors, who are being wooed India source much-needed capital, will also be concerned latest allegations poor management exchange. In one its most damaging passages, inspectors' report alleges that D S Prabhoodas, leading firm headed Mr Hemendra Kothari, former BSE president, and Mr Jaswant Chotalal, member BSE's governing body, avoided margin payments totalling Rs185.4m (Pounds 4.08m). Mr Kothari said yesterday that most transactions covered report were off-exchange deals directly financial institutions which margin payments were not required. Mr M R Mayya, BSE's executive director, said BSE rules permitted such bilateral off-exchange transactions. Sebi also accused exchange mismanaging administration its building. This week's argument is only latest series disputes which began almost soon Sebi started operations year ago. It was established Mr Manmohan Singh, finance minister, crucial element financial reform. Brokers claim Sebi is heavy-handed and fails understand their needs. They say rules must be applied flexibly and many firms are extremely small and unable carry cost extra regulations. But finance minister is backing Sebi hilt and singled it out praise his recent budget speech. Finance ministry officials believe loose regulations allow brokers and dodge taxes and also contributed last year's securities market scandal which banks, including UK's Standard Chartered Bank, lost combined gross total Rs40bn. The 29-storey Jijobhoy Towers, home Bombay Stock Exchange, was rocked two powerful bombs last Friday, leaving 60 dead and 200 injured. The market reopened Monday attempt return normal. It has had compromise - trading has been restricted hour day, and dealing has moved back traditional ring, where it stopped year ago. Dealers seemed this, BSE index rising 5.6 cent Monday and Tuesday. But another bomb blast Calcutta triggered nervous selling yesterday, and index came back 50.62, or 2.1 cent, 2,409.23. All this has taken place volatile background: Bombay equity market, six weeks or so, has had contend first unusually bullish speculation, national budget February 27, and subsequently some savage expressions disappointment. Dr Manmohan Singh, Indian finance minister, disappointed traders budget end last month. He postponed corporate tax reforms year, denying hopes tax cut recommended expert group. He reduce excise and import duties broad front, left out cement and steel sectors, where share prices had been boosted pre-budget speculation. To top it all, Dr Singh refused equate domestic investors their overseas counterparts taxing short-term capital gains. He lowered tax 30 cent 65 cent expatriate Indians and foreign investors local investors it remained 44.5 cent. Taking tax concessions granted, traders had driven share prices February make kill later. Instead, budget turned out be nightmare. While industry and business welcomed statement which, once, not propose any new tax, Professor Rusi Taraporewala, stock market theorist and academic, said reduction import duties would leave corporate profits ex-growth this year. The relative lack financial concessions meant that disappointed traders sold vengeance and, weekend, market seemed bottomless equity prices plummeted 13-month low. Overseas investors fuelled downtrend they sold some half million shares Reliance Industries, arbitraging share price Bombay stock exchange and market price its Euro-issue global depository receipts (GDRs). The opportunity arose change Indian regulations which allows international investors convert GDRs underlying stock. At current conversion rate Rs31 US dollar, Reliance GDR fetched Rs170 share BSE quotation Rs210. The BSE 30-share index plunged more one-fifth 2,287 March 10, 2,893 post-budget trading session February 27. Share prices rebounded last week, taking index 2,361 and uptrend, balance, has continued this week spite bomb blast Friday. Whether or not surge will turn strong rally will depend ability bulls maintain their momentum. They are hoping that foreign portfolio investment will pick restoration trading 'Black Friday', and successful sale Reliance stock BSE international investors. The Indian stock markets have been passing series crises December, when activists Bhartiya Janta party pulled Babri mosque Ayodhya, sparking communal riots. Mr Mark Bulloch Jardine Fleming takes domestic political situation his stride. 'Nothing dramatic has happened far foreign investors are concerned,' he says. 'They are appraising political situation.' In meantime, there is no compulsion local investors sell. In this, they are more fortunate they were previous years, when they were pressure take advantage long-term capital gains tax exemption financial year ended March. The exemption has been replaced flat 20 cent tax this year which, according dealers, puts bulls and bears footing. THE INDIAN government flew federal paramilitary troops Bombay last night more dozen bombs exploded city, killing 200 people and injuring more thousand. The devices, mostly car bombs, appeared be systematic attack India's commercial heart. All exploded 90 minutes afternoon. Among targets were Bombay Stock Exchange, landmark Air India building, shopping complex, and two hotels airport. The identity bombers was unknown, attacks were severe setback India's attempts heal wounds created recent intercommunal violence, which has caused deep shock throughout India. More 2,000 people died riots, including 700 Bombay, razing mosque Ayodhya northern India Hindu zealots December 6. The bombs appeared designed stir renewal communal strife and undermine efforts government Mr PV Narasimha Rao open economy and attract foreign investment and tourism. One targets was close headquarters Shiv Sena, Hindu nationalist party accused fomenting violence riots, which most victims were Moslems. National and local state leaders appealed calm attempt prevent renewed outbreak violence. Mr Rao urged nation ignore rumours 'inhuman and criminal bomb blasts'. Mr Sharad Pawar, former federal defence minister just re-appointed chief minister Maharashtra state, said all roads Bombay had been blocked and army put alert. He said: 'It is aimed disrupting economy and it appears conscious effort because only Bombay seems be target.' Mr Shankarrao Chavan, federal home (interior) minister, told parliament New Delhi: 'We suspect international conspiracy.' The Indian High Commission London said attacks were 'part externally supported terrorism which has targeted India some time'. However, Indian officials stopped short directly accusing Pakistan, country's arch-enemy. The bomb attacks were spread throughout city and were clearly aimed city's better-off business people - contrast riots which victims were mainly poor. At 28-storey stock exchange building, 3,000 people were second-storey trading floor when bomb exploded underground car park, hurling shards glass floor and street. Some victims were crushed stampede escape. Outside, burned bodies lay litter shattered buildings. MR TEG BAHADUR Thapar was serving lunch his stall Bombay stock exchange Friday when he was showered flying glass and broken concrete one 13 explosions which rocked city and left least 255 people killed and 1,200 injured. 'I'm lucky be alive,' he said his hospital bed. 'Who this? Who can stop this happening again?' Across Bombay people were asking themselves same questions this weekend. They sensed there was enormous difference riots which scarred city December and again January. Those were caused traditional mix crime, political agitation and ancient Hindu-Moslem hatreds stirred destruction mosque Ayodhya. The weapons used were mostly primitive - knives, clubs and petrol bottles. Friday's outrage, contrast, bears deadly stamp high-technology terrorism, complete Semtex plastic explosive, high-grade timers, efficient organisation and money. The only comparable previous incident was assassination 1991 Mr Rajiv Gandhi, former prime minister, Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger terrorists. But that was single bomb aimed one man - explosions Bombay were designed terrorise nation's commercial capital. Bombay accounts 35 cent India's exports. Mr P V Narasimha Rao, prime minister, described blasts attack India's economy. The immediate assumption highest level and streets Bombay was that those responsible must have been foreigners or had foreign help. But these suggestions were seen Bombay deliberate attempt deflect attention people who popular mind are real suspects - Moslem extremists who might have taken revenge riots which hit India Ayodhya mosque's destruction and which left 2,000 dead, including 700 Bombay. If Moslems are found have staged attacks, Indian authorities will certainly suspect that operation was supported Moslem country, notably Pakistan. The implications would be vast. Breaking diplomatic relations would be minimum step Delhi could take dangerous road. Mr Rao chose his words carefully his visit Bombay: 'There is definite possibility that our search may not stop country. I do not want name anybody because it will have ramifications and country.' There is no evidence linking attacks Moslem extremists, let alone Pakistan. Even if Moslem groups are found be responsible bombings, they could have been supplied other Moslem countries. India would still face diplomatic crisis hardly same scale. For moment, such concerns seem remote streets Bombay, where atmosphere yesterday was calm. Workmen were clearing away rubble blast sites, including blackened stock exchange building. Bombayites seemed determined put outrage them. At Gymkhana Club and dozens other sports grounds, hundreds men and boys were playing cricket they do every Sunday. Others were walking seafront arch Gateway India. The stock exchange authorities plan re-start trading soon they can  -probably today - using old trading floor exchange vacated only last year. Businessmen estimated main loss city would be loss life and injuries and damage caused blasted buildings. They not expect same widespread disruption production occurred riots. Some credit limited disruption should go government and police promptly calling paramilitary and regular troops help patrol sensitive districts. But much more should go people Bombay, who, so far least, have refused be goaded violent protest bombers.
column5: Trials and Tribulation of the Bombay Stock Exchange
column6: In March 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange survived a wave of selling, governmental criticism, a bomb attack that killed at least 255 people, another bombing in Calcutta killing 45, and the looming threat of war and rioting to reverse the downward trend and head upward again.
column7: In early March 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) reacted to a postponement of tax reform. By March 10 the BSE index sunk to a 13-month low at 2,287. On March 12 a coordinated bomb attack against targets in Bombay including the BSE killed at least 255 people and injured 1,200 threatening a resumption of Hindu-Moslem rioting which had occurred earlier. The BSE reopened on March 15, but on March 16 an explosion in Calcutta killed at least 45. Despite the tragedies and threat of war or rioting, the BSE index had climbed up as far as 2,409.23 by March 17.
column8: In March of 1993 the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) experienced a series of shocks, but emerged on the upbeat. The first blow was reaction to a report from the Indian finance minister on February 27 postponing corporate tax reform. Disappointed with the postponement, traders sold with a vengeance driving equity prices to a 13-month low with the BSE index down to 2,287 on March 10 compared to 2,893 on February 27. Then the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) accused the BSE of violating regulations limiting speculative investments. On the night of March 12 the BSE was damaged as thirteen bombs exploded in Bombay killing at least 255 people, injuring over 1,200 and threatening resumption of intercommunal riots between Hindus and Moslems. Despite structural damage, the BSE reopened on March 15. On March 16 an explosion in a residential district of Calcutta killed at least 45. A Sikh group claimed responsibility but official Indian comments implied that Pakistan was the main suspect. With the looming threat of riots and war, the BSE index rose by 2.1 per cent on March 15 and even after the Calcutta bombing settled at 2,409.23 on March 17, a marked improvement over the March 10 reading.
column9: Bombay Stock Exchange fights for equilibrium through bombs and investigations.
column10: The Bombay Stock Exchange has suffered a week of onslaught but remains open.  With the market already down 48 percent in not much more than a year, the exchange was accused of violating rules.  India's commercial heart, including the exchange, was bombed on Friday and more explosions hit Calcutta on Wednesday.
column11: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) remains open following a week of onslaught.  First the Securities and Exchange Board of India accused the market of ignoring and failing to enforce rules.  The Indian market already had fallen 48 percent since early last year, aggravated by a negative reaction to the Indian budget.  On Friday afternoon, India's commercial heart, including the BSE, was hit with car bombs.  While a militant Sikh group claimed responsibility, Indian officials still suspect Moslem extremists seeking a return of communal strife.  The BSE was able to resume limited trading, but a slight rise was halted by an explosion Wednesday in Calcutta.
column12: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) remains open following a week of onslaught.  Last week, the Securities and Exchange Board of India completed its first inspection of the books and accused the market of ignoring and failing to enforce rules.  This is just the latest dispute between the government and the troubled BSE.  The Indian market already had fallen 48 percent since early last year, aggravated by a negative reaction to the Indian budget, which helped foreign and expatriate investors, but did not provide the expected tax relief to local industry.  On Friday afternoon, the BSE, along with other Bombay commercial centers, was hit with car bombs.  These attacks struck at the heart of India's commerce, seemingly aimed at undermining government efforts to expand foreign investment and tourism.  While a militant Sikh group claimed responsibility, Indian officials still suspect Moslem extremists, maybe with Pakistani help, seeking revenge for the December 1992 destruction of a mosque in northern India.  The BSE was able to resume limited trading on Monday and the index rose for two days.  This rise was halted by an explosion Wednesday, which killed 45 and injured a score in a central Calcutta apartment complex.  Fears abound that communal strife will return.

column3: THE revelation that John Major is capable candid, blunt and salty language when talking off-the- record friendly journalists has surprised some people. It has been suggested that recording prime minister's conversation Michael Brunson, ITN's political editor, which Major used variety four-, six- and eight-letter words communicate his lack fondness certain colleagues, may do him good. With luck, it is reckoned, Major's image leaden-tongued wimp may undergo correction. What piffle. Major is gonner, especially this week's revolt wooden-tops Christchurch by-election, where Conservative majority 23,015 last year's general election was converted 16,427 majority Liberal Democrats. Fifteen months too late, voters Christchurch rounded Tories malignant and squeaky fury. In reality, all politicians, not just Major, are far more candid and salty when chatting private when speaking public. In public, they have be careful what they say, so their utterances achieve horrible mattness. But private they relax. Their syntax disappears. Their words become nonsensical. They swear and joke and shout. It really is spectacle. To show you what I mean, I spoke yesterday John Major and John Smith. Smith, Scot, is leader Labour Party, though not many people know that. In aftermath Christchurch, where Labour lost its deposit, I wanted provoke two Johns spot real soul-searching. To guarantee them privacy, I used signal-scrambler. No one could have eavesdropped. Their responses were true form. But I have left out swear-words because new Financial Times Style Guide states that 'the gratuitous use expletives or obscenities is discouraged . . . Four-letter expletives will be confined infrequent use review (Arts) pages.' I can live that, though why artsy-fartsies should receive any dispensation is puzzle. First, I tackled Major. I said: 'Did you read, John, what Olivier Blanchard, Rudiger Dornbusch, Stanley Fischer, Franco Modigliani, Paul A Samuelson and Robert Solow wrote, just one article, FT this week? They were describing Europe's lunatic monetary policies and exchange rate arrangements. They not pull their punches. I bet you went chalk-white. 'So why not walk plank, John? You are most unpopular prime minister start fourth century. Why invite more punishment? Unfairly or not, you are drawing blame all life's unpleasantnesses, let alone cock-ups.' 'Are you sure?' prime minister replied. 'I mean . . . how it come about, Michael . . . like, Christchurch, y'know - load . . . let me put it you - economy, course . . . I mean, wimpy guy me. But I'm not giving that, . . .' On and it went. Then I rang John Smith. I told him I had been impressed his interview Andrew Marr The Independent Thursday, which he sharpened his promise introduce meaty political reforms (if he ever gets elected), including referendum proportional representation. I said: 'You are starting raise your game, John. Many people will have agreed your assertion that democracy Britain is decaying, and that Tories must be roasted their arrogance, incompetence, complacency and sharp practices - especially their 'centralisation power and elimination opposition'. But some your critics still accuse you, John, laziness and ineffectualness. What do you say that?' 'Away, ye thowless jad,' shouted Labour leader. 'Gie me o'wit an' sense life, behint kist lie an' sklent. Our Stibble-rig was Rab M'Graen, clever, sturdy fellow, then he was sae fley'd his showther gae keek, an' tumbl'd wi' wintle. Likewise political and constitutional reform, Michael, L - - d, tho' I should beg wi'lyart pow, I'll laugh, an' sing, an' shake my leg, lang's I dow]' After that, I thought telephoning Wing-Commander Paddy Ashdown, leader Liberal Democrats, solicit his views Christchurch. But I couldn't raise energy. Last year biography Mrs Norma Major - or, if we are being old-fashioned, Mrs John Major - claimed that Majors' favourite film was Being There. I entirely concur their choice. In case you not see that marvellous film, this, essence, was plot: man no one knows anything about, gardener called Chauncey, rises trace become, end film, serious candidate US presidency. Chauncey, played Peter Sellers, utters only mundane sentiments halting monotone this convinces Republican party's power brokers that he is sure-fire winner. In Chauncey's bromides everyone seems hear what they want believe. He has deadly innocence. No wonder Majors liked this film. John Major must, some level, have appreciated similarity his own, strangely intangible, rise and that Chauncey's. If he not see similarity, that is still more revealing. Do not protest that urban John Major could not identify gardener. In interview Farmers Weekly, few days ago, Major disclosed unknown fact: his father was once farmer. Farmers Weekly, you see, had asked Major how he had 'such obvious empathy agriculture'. (Well, it was obvious Farmers Weekly, anyway.) And Major replied: 'It's simple. My father was farmer. He lived small farm somewhere Shropshire.' Francis Wheen The Guardian, keen student Major's mysterious past, immediately rang 10 Downing Street, which claimed that Major's father farmed Bromsgrove 1910. As Wheen pointed out, Major was unresponsive 33 years old that time, and - minor point this - Bromsgrove is not Shropshire. This, course, does not mean that Major made everything up. Family folklore is peculiar thing. Yet when I heard this, my mind immediately went back incident few months ago, when Major visited Pittsburgh, centre US steel industry, part his American tour. I recall that he made great hit recounting that his father had been steelworker city. A farmer Farmers Weekly, Pittsburgh steelworker American audience . . . pattern emerges. Major's father, and therefore extension John Major himself, can be all things all people. If John Major were different sort politician, this would be point barely worth making. But it does seem all piece Major's approach wider political issues. On one hand he will appeal pro-Europeans his party claiming want Britain be heart Europe. On other he is free insulting references European Commission, whenever it is necessary appeal audience Euro-sceptics. There are those who will argue that this merely means that Major is typical democratic politician, that one who wants become prime minister democracy must recognise many constituencies interest, not just one. But that has not been true Major's most recent Conservative predecessors. Margaret Thatcher was notoriously dogmatic, public, and so too was Edward Heath, though he always pretended be 'consensus politician'. No, Major's technique is very much his invention, very much reflection his particular character, itself product his unsettled family background. His father, Tom Major-Ball, was itinerant figure, moving place place, trying his hand any number occupations, including circus. No wonder young John Major learned skill fitting prevailing circumstances, no matter how fluctuating. The only problem is old one: you cannot fool all people all time. Except movies. Dominic Lawson is editor The Spectator ONE year ago tomorrow, Mr John Major surprised everyone himself winning general election. His honeymoon, very personal victory, was short-lived and now he begins second year his hard-won term deeply unpopular leader who has everything still prove. The 12 months have been hijacked internal party differences Europe, debacle surrounding UK withdrawal exchange rates mechanism European Monetary System, and continuing, deep recession which has disappointed and alienated many traditional Tory supporters business. Mr Major's anniversary inevitably led yesterday outbreak political point-scoring government's record. While Mr Tony Newton, leader Commons, conceded: 'No one pretends that last year has been easy,' he also claimed that much had been achieved. The government's efforts secure framework long-term prosperity was beginning pay off. Mr John Smith, Labour leader, was joined 10 frontbench colleagues launching counter-attack, involving detailed and documented indictment Mr Major's failures. He attacked Tories building 'a bonfire pre-election commitments'. Tory allegiances business world have also been put immense pressure, though criticism policy drift and inaction may soften recession ends. Yesterday Sir Michael Angus, president Confederation British Industry, remained cautious volunteered: 'If I were betting man I would say we have embryo recovery.' Mr Major can take little comfort conclusion, widespread industrialists, that his greatest achievement year has been Britain's withdrawal ERM - something which he resisted and which, end, he had no control. Most industrialists, however, find it hard criticise Mr Major individual, many drawing flattering parallel his personal qualities and those his predecessor. He still attracts gratitude election victory, which was seen - subsequent problems economy - best result business. But, previous No 10 occupant, he is seen weak leader, little vision and bereft clearly articulated political conviction. There is general perception that, important though Britain's future place Europe is, prime minister has been excessively preoccupied community affairs and associated internal party ructions, detriment domestic economy. Many industrialists are pleased that Mr Major is now attempting reshape economic strategy favour manufacturing base. But jury is out whether rhetoric will give way effective action.  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- The first 12 months - election victory initial Maastricht defeat  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- APRIL Wins election 21 seat majority 'The country looked Labour government eye and decided that it was not all Time Change' - Peter Jenkins, late political commentator 'We have won tonight magnificent victory, victory many people thought our grasp' - Major  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- MAY Best Conservative local election results 13 years England and Wales. Tories win control 126 councils  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JUNE Rio Summit No new British aid finance conference decisions, only proposal 'Darwin initiative' exchange information endangered species. 'I came here low expectations and all those have been met' - Jonathon Porritt, environmental campaigner 'I believe that short and long term, people will look back and say that Rio we took decisive step' - Major  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JULY Britain takes EC presidency 'Those whom gods would destroy they first grant presidency European Council Ministers' - Mark Almond, Fellow Institute European Defence and Strategic Studies  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- AUGUST Two-day Yugoslav peace conference 30 nations is presented triumph international diplomacy John Major and UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros Ghali 'Talks, what talks?' - Serbian president, Slobodan Milosevic he storms out while Major is speaking  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- SEPTEMBER Black Wednesday Bank England interest rates rise 15 cent government takes sterling out EMS. 'The sky is darkening wings chickens coming home roost' - Lord Callaghan 'There is going be no devaluation, no realignment, deflationary option would be betrayal our future and it is not government policy' - Major  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- OCTOBER Mining closures U-turn Michael Heseltine announces review 21 31 pits threat 'I'm just getting used being more popular John Major' - Arthur Scargill 'What has happened is development what was government's mind. We have listen what people say' - Major  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- NOVEMBER Matrix Churchill inquiry John Major challenged claims he had 'specific' and 'personal' knowledge that Matrix Churchill exported machine tools Iraq munitions manufacture. 'Either ministers do not know what is going their departments, or they were not prepared tell' - Allan Rogers, Labour's former defence procurement spokesman  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- DECEMBER Edinburgh conference Concessions granted Danes hope voters will approve Maastricht second referendum. Agreement EC spending levels, Maastricht back track ratification  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JANUARY Major launches libel action New Statesman & Society and Scallywag allegations linking him businesswoman Claire Latimer. 'It is not our intention slur prime minister' - Steve Platt, editor New Statesman  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- FEBRUARY Unemployment tops 3m 'Provided circumstances are right there is no reason why we shouldn't bounce back this time' - Gillian Shephard, secretary state employment  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- MARCH Maastricht debate More 40 Tory MPs revolt first Commons defeat Maastricht treaty legislation, defying Major's appeal party unity 'When they started out they weren't household names their homes' - David Mellor Tory Euro-rebels  ----------------------------------------------------------------------- John Major, endorsed Margaret Thatcher politician closest her heart, was elected Conservative Party Tuesday night succeed her prime minister. Major, 47, fell two votes short winning majority voting 372 Coservative Party members Parliament, his two opponents quickly conceded defeat and party confirmed Major winner. Mrs. Thatcher, ending 11{ years power, intended submit her resignation Queen Elizabeth II Wednesday morning, and Major would then be called lead government. Major, chancellor exchequer, emerged his official residence 11 Downing St. Tuesday night smiling and holding hands his wife, Norma. Inside, Mrs. Thatcher, who came next door prime minister's 10 Downing Street residence, embraced Major. I am thrilled and delighted that John Major is succeed me, Iron Lady said statement released aides. It is very exciting thing become leader Conservative Party, and particularly exciting, I think, follow one most remarkable leaders Conservative Party has ever had, Major said. Our job now I think is quite clear. We are going unite totally and absolutely, and we're going win next general election, said Major, who will be youngest British prime minister this century. Major received 185 votes, two short majority. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine received 131 and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd had 56. Hurd and Heseltine conceded minutes, and party officials declared Major elected. The party had been torn sudden and unexpected leadership challenge Heseltine, who last week stopped Mrs. Thatcher short victory first leadership race. Mrs. Thatcher had not wanted leave office, she decided resign last week she was unable put Heseltine's challenge. She said she resigned let someone Cabinet stand Heseltine. Major and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd joined race, vote her aides spread word that she was backing Major. The son circus performer and one time welfare recipient, Major personifies values self-reliance and hard work that Mrs. Thatcher had preached nation. His election climaxed month British politics-turned-upside down, and Western world's longest-serving head government was driven office revolt party ranks. Heading government that was trailing opposition Labor Party polls and suffering losing streak local Parliamentary elections, Mrs. Thatcher lost control events her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, resigned Nov. 1. Howe, fourth Cabinet member resign because disputes policy European Community, shocked House Commons Nov. 13 calling Mrs. Thatcher threat Britain's vital interests. The next day, Heseltine announced he would challenge her. Six days later, Mrs. Thatcher 34-nation summit Paris officially ending Cold War, Heseltine polled enough votes deny her re-election leader. Two days later, she decided resign party leaders told her she could not win. Heseltine, 57, said Major's election lays basis unity our party. Hurd said party needed unite, and John Major is right leader this task. Opposition leaders derided Major's election Thatcherism different face. The Conservatives' main rivals, socialist Labor Party, demanded general election. John Major is Thatcherette - that is how he sought election and that is how he got elected, said Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. It means that policies that brought poll tax, recession, heavy mortgages and rising unemployment will go on. During his five-day campaign, Major had aaid he would review poll tax, unpopular local tax brought Mrs. Thatcher, he gave no other hints differing her. While adopting gentler tone contentious issue Britain's involvement Europe, he shares her opposition single European currency and shares her belief tight restraint government spending. However, he insisted weekend, I am not running `Son Thatcher.' I am running myself, my priorities and my programs. Major's victory ended patient, four-year campaign Heseltine promote himself future leader party. Tomorrow always dawns, he said, smiling conceding defeat. Major was elected Parliament 1979, was appointed foreign secretary and then chancellor exchequer last year. He moved quickly leadership race. By weekend, opinion polls showed that Major was nearly highly regarded public was Heseltine, who has been prominent decade. Major attracted support figures right wing Conservative Party, although his friends insisted Major's views were more liberal many supposed. He described himself conservative economic issues liberal social issues.
column5: Major Defeat; Prime Minister Leads Tories to Third Party Status
column6: The Tories will make Prime Minister John Major, protege of Margaret Thatcher, the scapegoat for their stunning defeat in local elections across Britain in May. Though he won the 1992 general election, the high-school dropout is now accused of being a weak leader, incompetent on both domestic and international issues.
column7: On Easter Sunday, three Cabinet ministers issued statements on behalf of  Prime Minister John Major amidst speculation that he could be forced out this autumn. In May local elections across Britain, however, the Conservatives loss 444 seats, and word circulated that Major was not up to the job.Major became leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister after his mentor, Margaret Thatcher resigned under pressure in 1990. Though he won the 1992 general election, the lingering recession and controversies involving European community issues splintered the Tories. He came to be viewed as a weak, vacillating leader, lacking political conviction.
column8: In early May elections across Britain, the Conservatives suffered their worst defeat ever, losing 444 seats. One editorial claims some Conservatives will link the defeats to Prime Minister John Major, and there is speculation that he could be forced out this autumn.A former welfare recipient, John Major was elected Conservative Party leader and successor to his mentor Margaret Thatcher when she resigned under pressure in November 1990. After Mrs. Thatcher submitted her seals of office, Major was called by Queen Elizabeth II to form a new government, and it was expected that there would be no significant policy shift. Major's comment while visiting America a month later that Iraqi troops might have to be "forcibly removed" from Kuwait echoed Mrs. Thatcher's hard-line on the Persian Gulf.Within a year of winning the general election, his popularity had plunged. In the July 1993 Christchurch by-election the Conservative majority of 23,015 the previous year was converted into a 16,427 majority for the Liberal Democrats. Though Major's personal style is preferable to that of Mrs. Thatcher, he is characterized as a vacillating, weak leader, lacking vision and political conviction. Not even recent revelations that Major uses salty language can alter his wimp image.
column9: John Major elected leader of Conservative Party, becomes next Prime Minister.
column10: John Major emerged victorious in an election for leadership of the Conservative Party and became, at 47, Britain's youngest prime minister. His popularity began to decline very soon after his election and he is viewed and weak and indecisive. Having reneged on campaign promises, he is blamed for the recession which plagues Britain.
column11: At 47, John Major became Britain's youngest prime minister. His accession to power followed the surprise resignation of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher following a challenge by former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine to her leadership. Major fell two votes shy of a victory in an election with Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and Heseltine but both opponents quickly conceded to Major. Since his election, Major has been seen as weak and indecisive. He is an unpopular leader whose cabinet has been rocked by scandal and who reneged on campaign promises. Adding to his unpopularity is the recession which continues plague Britain.
column12: John Major was 47 when he was elected to lead the Conservative Party. Assuming the position of prime Minister from Margaret, Mr. Major became the youngest prime minister since the 19th century. Mr. Major was confirmed as leader of the Conservative Party when his two opponents, former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, conceded defeat in an election which saw Major two votes shy of a majority. Major, whose father was a trapeze artist in the circus, overcame many obstacles in his rise to the top. He was a high school drop out and for a time was a welfare recipient. Mr. Major had little time to enjoy his victory as public opinion of him soon soured. While seen as gentler than his abrasive predecessor, he is viewed as timid and indecisive. Almost from the first he has been beset by scandal in his cabinet and a number of controversies ranging from internal party differences over Europe to the debacle surrounding Britain's withdrawal from the exchange rates mechanism of the European Monetary System to a deep and continuing recession. Major came out in strong support of U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf, calling on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait.

column3: Japanese writer Kazuo Ishiguro won 1989 Booker Prize, Britain's top literary award, his novel The Remains Day, judges announced Thursday. The prize is worth $32,000. Judges praised novel, love story butler's English vacation, cunningly structured and beautifully paced performance. Other finalists this year were Canadian Margaret Atwood Cat's Eye, Irish author John Banville Book Evidence, Scotland's James Kelman A Disaffection and English writers Sybille Bedford Jigsaw and Rose Tremain Restoration. After receiving prize, Ishiguro paid tribute Salman Rushdie, 1988 runner-up award, who went hiding February when he was threatened death Moslems who said his novel The Satanic Verses blasphemed their faith. Now that circumstances have changed, when perhaps it is inconvenient many people support his writing, I just felt it was fitting that we should not turn our backs him, Ishiguro said. Rushdie lives England. Ishiguro, 39, arrived England age 6 and now lives south London. He writes English. In announcing winner, judges said: `The Remains Day' renders humor and pathos memorable character and explores large, vexed themes class, tradition and duty. It was narrowly preferred universally admired. Ishiguro was finalist Booker Prize 1986 his novel An Artist Floating World. The Booker Prize is sponsored Booker, international food and agriculture business. After hours heated delib-eration - system described 'mad' one judge - Pounds 20,000 Booker Prize fiction last night went Mr James Kelman How Late It Was, How Late, published Secker and Warburg. The novel, story Scottish low-life narrated largely Glaswegian dialect, is unlikely prove popular choice booksellers, who have damned all six books shortlisted prize boring, elitist and - worst all - unsaleable. Professor John Bayley, chairman Booker judges, acknowledged that Mr Kelman's book particular might be deemed inaccessible. 'We had extremely difficult final meeting and were very divided,' he said three hours debate. Rabbi Julia Neuberger, only woman judging panel, said she was made extremely cross decision. 'It's just drunken Scotsman railing bureaucracy,' she said. 'My eyes are stretched disbelief. The voting system is completely mad. Kelman was least favourite three front runners. If it had been short story it would have been fine.' Mr Kelman's book is, according some observers, most difficult work have won prize. In his acceptance speech, Mr Kelman, perceived some Scottish isolationist, anticipated criticism, declaring: 'My culture and my language have right exist.' One guest prize-giving dinner London's Guildhall, Mr Salman Rushdie, who won prize 1981 Midnight's Children, remarked: 'James Kelman is good, not good he thinks he is.' The Booker prize has, its 26-year history, always provoked controversy. But this year's rows have been particularly fine vintage. Prof Bayley went record rousing condemnation contemporary fiction. Another judge, Mr James Wood, literary critic The Guardian, was attacked failing reveal that young novelist being considered award, Ms Claire Messud, was fact Mrs James Wood. Most damaging all was verdict booksellers, who dismissed shortlist narcoleptic. The other contenders were The Folding Star Alan Hollinghurst, Beside Ocean Time George Mackay Brown, Paradise Abdulrazak Gurnah, Reef Romesh Gunesekera and Knowledge Angels Jill Paton Walsh. In spite heavy publicity, novels nominated have been selling 50 cent less last year's shortlist. Last year's winner, Roddy Doyle's Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha, sold 350,000 copies. 'Kelman's novel is unlikely come anywhere that,' one bookseller said. Mr Kelman was also shortlisted prize 1989 his novel A Disaffection. It is sensational shortlist: bestseller love and hypnotism, blockbuster battles and brides Ruritania, and pornographic shocker teenage sex and baby murder so explicit that only obscure Newcastle publisher would risk printing it. Out are eminences gris Victorian letters - novels Thomas Hardy and Mrs Humphry Ward, who advised Gladstone and Roosevelt, didn't make grade. This week shortlist hypothetical 1894 Booker Prize will be announced six judges, including biographer Victoria Glendinning and broadcaster Melvyn Bragg. They have avoided dull and worthy classics and chosen six books which stirred fin de siecle world and remain compelling today: George du Maurier's Trilby, Anthony Hope's The Prisoner Zenda, George Moore's Esther Waters, Kipling's Jungle Book, George Gissing's In Year Jubilee and RL Stevenson's The Ebb Tide. The winner will be revealed October 15 (four days 1994 Booker Prize ceremony) Cheltenham Festival Literature. Like today's Booker Prize, it is publishing gimmick; Everyman, which is backing spoof award, is significant publisher classic Victorian novels. But retrospective Booker is also fascinating exercise historical reconstruction. It raises questions how relationship literature and society has changed 100 years. First, similarities. A good yarn is good yarn. Of 1894 books, Trilby is tale tone-deaf model who sings angel when mesmerised sinister hypnotist Svengali, then croaks crow when he dies one her concerts. The Prisoner Zenda tells Englishman impersonating King Ruritania and rescuing him demons. On 1994 list Romesh Guneskera's Reef is Sri Lankan servant boy and his mysterious master, while Jill Paton Walsh's Knowledge Angels re-enacts wolf-child legend. All books lists are gripping stories. The lists share key themes. Both, instance, have books colonial exploitation - Stevenson's The Ebb Tide and Abdulrazak Gurnah's Paradise, which is set First World War German East Africa. Both provoke similar ways. The controversial books 1894 were Trilby, its louche vie boheme milieu, and Esther Waters, which 17-year-old girl is seduced, impregnated and offered services professional baby killer fiver. It is now seen Moore's best work, 1894 it had problems finding publisher and powerful circulating libraries refused take it. A century on, relationship fiction and sexual morality remains vexed. Last week, Times critic complained inclusion Alan Hollinghurst's candid novel homosexual love, The Folding Star, Booker list, because it offended Judaeo-Christian ethics. But if Hollinghurst wins Booker, his novel will not become succes de scandale Esther Waters and Trilby, which became bestselling novel 19th century. For great difference then and now is that 1894 Booker Prize was not needed sell fiction. Today, we accept gap literary writing, such Hollinghurst's, and popular bestsellers writers Jeffrey Archer and Barbara Cartland. This is gap Booker tries bridge giving high-level publicity works which would not normally reach mass audience. The trick works - last year's winner, Roddy Doyle's Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha sold 360,000 hardback copies. Before short-list was announced it sold 10,600. The Victorians, contrast, were lovers contemporary fiction. Novels accounted 20 cent published books, and no distinction was made high and low art. In mid 19th century, Dickens made Pounds 12,000 Little Dorrit, equivalent nearly Pounds 400,000 today. Between 1861 and 1894, when population UK was half that today and literate population smaller still, Mrs Henry Wood's East Lynne sold 400,000 copies. All 1894 Booker writers were popular names; they were also serious, skilful writers whose books can be reread pleasure 100 years later. Why was fiction so much closer public heart 1894? Social, cultural and psychological reasons play part. Socially, 1890s reading public was vastly more homogenous group today: small number middle class authors wrote middle class audience time when be literate was belong elite. The idea two-tier, and down-market, fiction was irrelevant. Culturally, these writers and readers were certain their place mainstream, and novel was their political and intellectual forum. Today we no longer share Victorian confidence novel key genre our age. Modernism and overturning traditional form Joyce and Woolf weakened 20th-century belief novel and encouraged divergence highbrow and lowbrow. The dominance film and television has made novels more marginal form and perhaps they no longer attract most creative talents. George du Maurier originally offered outline Trilby Henry James, who he thought would write better novel. Today du Maurier would have sold it Hollywood or BBC. The fantasy element fiction, which we identify characters if we know them, was answered 19th century novel; 20th century we have TV soaps. Just tabloid newspapers feature characters EastEnders, so when Dickens' The Old Curiosity Shop was running serial there was widespread press speculation whether Little Nell would die, and readers wrote begging her be saved. Sentimentality, accessibility, topicality - what characterises today's soaps were clear features novel 1894. Both In Year Jubilee and Esther Waters, example, centre burning 1890s debate marriage, feminism and 'New Woman', are also tearjerkers which everyone enjoyed. The 1894 books are compelling because they prefigure our times and are set back them. Trilby is tale hypnotism and unconscious decade away Freud; The Ebb Tide paved way Conrad's Heart Darkness and first questioning colonial oppression. It is unlikely that 1994 Booker choices will speak eloquently new trends today. Whereas 1894 titles had contemporary settings, many 1994 books are historical (such Paradise) or are driven nostalgia (such Beside Ocean Time). Which book will win October 15? Stevenson will get sympathy vote because he died 1894 Samoa, setting The Ebb Tide. Jungle Book will get retrospective vote, because it is best-known today and has fashionable mythic overtones lost paradise Mowgli's jungle; its position list may also rescue it schmaltzy Disney associations and confirm it serious novel young man's self-discovery. My vote goes Trilby. Soft-focus, ideologically shaky - its anti-Semitic portrait Svengali - and sometimes sloppy, it is story demonic possession and haunts imagination fairy tale long better-written works have faded memory. Like Rebecca, popular novel du Maurier's granddaughter, it is natural equivalent what current Booker Prize seeks create: combination classic and bestseller. The shortlist six Pounds 20,000 Booker Prize fiction, announced yesterday, immediately prompted question 'Who?' many publishing industry. According one insider, some list 'are B-team writers best'. The six include Alan Hollinghurst's The Folding Star (published Chatto and Windus), melancholy study homosexual obsession which was tipped likely candidate initial 'long list' 15, The Reef (Granta) young Sri Lankan writer Romesh Gunesekera and How Late It Was, How Late (Secker and Warburg) gritty Glasgow realist James Kelman, which was almost universally well-reviewed. As other three - Knowledge Angels (Green Bay) philosophical fable children's author Jill Paton Walsh, Paradise (Hamish Hamilton) Zanzibar-born writer Abdulrazak Gurnah and Beside Ocean Time (John Murray) 72-year-old Orcadian poet George Mackay Brown - 'frankly, they don't make grade'. The shortlist Booker, UK's most hyped literary prize and one most lucrative, is all more surprising bumper year new fiction fulfilling criteria - English language and non-American - consideration award. Margaret Atwood's The Robber Bride seems astonishing omission, do new novels Peter Ackroyd, Peter Carey, Candia McWilliam, William Trevor and Jim Crace. But if shortlist final six candidates prize may be disappointing, traditional controversy surrounding award is rife ever. One unsurprising omission final selection was When The World Was Steady, first novel Claire Messud, which was 'long list' it was pointed out that author was wife James Wood, chief literary reviewer The Guardian newspaper and Booker judge. Professor John Bayley, chairman Booker panel and husband former Booker Prize winner Dame Iris Murdoch, expressed surprise Mr Wood's failure reveal his relationship Ms Messud. But it is final list, rather controversy, that discredits award according some critics. 'This list,' said one man letters, 'must have dealt final death blow Booker.' The trust is charity promoting reading and books and administers prize. The prize has become internationally known, and worldwide demand winning book, English and translations, is spectacular, said Shaw. The prize was first awarded 1969 talks Booker and Publishers' Association need significant literary award encourage and reward good writing. British publishers can submit three new novels British and Commonwealth writers. There were 110 submissions last year. A management committee authors, booksellers, librarians and sponsors chooses jury five: writer or two, academic, politician interested literature and literary editor or critic. Each juror reads every book submitted, lists six favorites and meets other jurors select and announce six finalists. As public debate rages who's in, who's out and who might win, bookmakers country calling odds, jurors meet again and finally select winner afternoon announcement day. This year's finalists: Beryl Bainbridge An Awfully Big Adventure, A.S. Byatt Possession, Penelope Fitzgerald The Gate Angels, John McGahern Amongst Women, Brian Moore Lies Silence and Mordecai Richler Solomon Gursky Was Here. Six novels have been nominated Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious fiction award, and bookmakers say favorite is The Remains Day Japanese author Kazuo Ishiguro. The award, be announced Oct. 26, carries $31,600 prize funded Booker McConnell food company. Oddsmaker William Hill gave 7-to-4 odds Ishiguro's novel butler's travels Britain's West Country and said it was firm favorite win. Ishiguro, previously nominated award, was beaten Booker favorite 1986, which makes his chances that much stronger this time our view, said William Hill spokesman Graham Sharpe. The other books nominated are:  Cat's Eye, story painter Elaine Risley and her return her childhood home Toronto Canadian author Margaret Atwood, also previous nominee.  The Book Evidence, prison story kidnap and murder convict Freddie Montgomery John Banville, literary editor The Irish Times newspaper.  Jigsaw, Sybille Bedford, autobiographical novel adolescent's travels Germany, Italy and France.  A Disaffection, Scottish novelist James Kelman's story school teacher, Patrick Doyle, whose professional frustrations are fueled drinking problem and unrequited love colleague.  Restoration, British author Rose Tremain's story Robert Merivel, favorite King Charles II who married monarch's youngest mistress. We expect more interest this year's Booker Prize ever before, partly thanks last year's controversy Salman Rushdie's `Satanic Verses,' Sharpe said. Rushdie was nominated prize last year it was won Australian author Peter Carey his love story Oscar and Lucinda. Rushdie, British citizen, has been hiding Feb. 14 when late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered he be killed allegedly blaspheming Islam Satanic Verses. This year's six nominees were chosen Thursday 102 books considered panel headed David Lodge, British literary critic and novelist who was nominated prize last year his book, Nice Work. On day Big Event, Ladbroke, large British betting agency, posted final odds.  Brian Moore was favorite 7-4, followed Peter Ackroyd (5-2), Iris Murdoch (3-1) and Chinua Achebe (9-2).  The two dark horses, Nina Bawden and Penelope Lively, were each tipped 7-1.You may have noticed distinctly literary tilt that lineup, affinity bookshelf, not bookie.  All those people published new works fiction here Britain 12 months.  And last few weeks, literary punters throughout British Isles have been placing bets which those writers would win Booker Prize, best-known, best-liked and, almost incidentally, most prestigious fiction award land.In recent weeks Booker contenders have received almost much press coverage Charles and Di rift.  And nearly every article, book reviews author interviews, has featured latest odds.  The betting is done largely literary insiders, says Graham Sharpe, who sets Booker odds William Hill, Britain's other big betting agency.  "They read books, hear gossip and want pull little coup themselves," he says.Last year's winner, "The Old Devils" Kingsley Amis, was 5-2 favorite, this year, anyone who chose victor made some dough."When she accepted her prize "Moon Tiger," Penelope Lively looked surprised and pleased.  "I'm not betting woman, and I have slight reservations books becoming spectator sport," she said soft Oxbridge tones.  "But those who are know tell me that 7-1 was irresistible flutter."  Her 65-year-old mother was those who made killing.America has Pulitzer Prize fiction and National Book Awards, terms excitement, hoopla and man-on-the-street interest, there's nothing akin 15,000-pound ($26,000) Booker Prize.  With possible exception France's respected Prix Goncourt, there's nothing quite it anywhere else.Britons wryly compare Booker Academy Awards, and though there's just one prize and no envelope, similarities exist.  There's team judges and pool candidates.  This year each British publisher could submit three new titles, grand total 93.  As one judge noted wearily, "By August, I was more slight panic, sometimes reading all day and evening; reading while standing bus stop, reading while cooking, reading, almost, while talking telephone."Next comes "short-list," judges' top six, which was announced great fanfare late September.  This year works included Brian Moore's political thriller "The Color Blood" (E.P.  Dutton, 182 pages, $16.95); Peter Ackroyd's "Chatterton" (Grove Press, 240 pages, $17.95); Nina Bawden's "Circles Deceit" (St. Martin's Press, 208 pages, $14.95); Iris Murdoch's 23rd novel "The Book and Brotherhood" (Viking, 608 pages, $19.95); Nigerian writer Chinua Achebe's "Anthills Savannah" (Doubleday, 240 pages, $16.95); and "Moon Tiger" (Grove Press, 216 pages, $15.95).The awards presentation came last Thursday October, and any major awards presentation, it came complete limousines, banquet (salmon mousse, champagne sorbet and English roast beef) and television cameras.  The suspense was genuine; judges chose winner just three hours announcement.To be sure, ratings prime-time broadcast didn't upstage those "Eastenders," Britain's popular soap opera.  Yet interest was sufficient Andre Deutsch, "Moon Tiger's" British publisher, order additional 20,000 copies almost minute Mrs. Lively -- and nation -- heard news.By British standards, sales figures recent Booker winners are stunning, "The Old Devils" (80,000 hard-cover copies) Anita Brookner's "Hotel du Lac" (40,000 copies).  Even Keri Hulme's "The Bone People," look Maori culture that most readers found impenetrable, reached respectable 21,000 1985.Short-listed authors are just few paces behind, sharing best-seller list Dick Francis and Scott Turow.  Heinemann initially printed 3,000 copies "Anthills Savannah," usual run contemporary literary fiction.  So far, 10,000 copies have sold.  "Being short-listed probably changed destiny that book," declares member Heinemann sales staff.  Indeed, there's currently talk initiating similar prize similar purse year's best biography.Another notable spinoff is Booker harpies, readers intent digesting all six titles, then vigorously disputing choices, which never please everyone.  This year Sunday Times offered readers complete autographed collection six books equivalent $112, perfect fodder literary cocktail party cot.It wasn't always this way, course.  Headlines were modest back 1969 when P.H. Newby won first ever Booker Prize "Something Answer For." (The wonderfully appropriate name comes Booker-McConnell PLC, international food and agriculture conglomerate that puts prize money each year.)The idea was devise British equivalent Prix Goncourt, and that august French award, Booker attracted attention minute it kicked controversy.  The early fuss was kept literary world, critics sniping choices and prize's varied ground rules.  The real world took notice 1974, when Elizabeth Jane Howard, one three judges, wrote letter Times claiming that her opinion Kingsley Amis's "Ending Up," one short-listed books, was his best ever.  As it happens, she was married Mr. Amis time.  He didn't win.But many credit Booker's current appeal 1982 competition and Thomas Keneally's "Schindler's Ark," or "Schindler's List" it is known U.S. Written novel, book told true story remarkable German who saved lives hundreds Jews concentration camps.  But it won Booker, people argued that it wasn't novel.  "The more people questioned it, more it sold," says Ion Trewin, editorial director Hodder & Stoughton.  "That was first year prize caught media and public imagination.  Suddenly Booker gained inches front pages."Oh yes, "Moon Tigers" is dying woman's recollection her life World War II war correspondent and her affair young tank officer.--- Ms. Trucco is free-lance writer based London. Australian novelist Peter Carey was awarded coveted Booker Prize fiction Tuesday night his love story, Oscar and Lucinda. A panel five judges unanimously announced award $26,250 prize 80-minute deliberation banquet London's ancient Guildhall. The judges made their selection 102 books published Britain 12 months and which they read their homes. Carey, who lives Sydney his wife and son, said brief speech that other five finalists he had been asked attend short speech his pocket case he won. If I'd known I was going win I think I would have taken bit more trouble my handwriting, he said he stared his notes. He was unsuccessful prize competition 1985 when his novel, Illywhacker, was final six. Carey called award great honor and he thanked prize sponsors provoking so much passionate discussion literature  perhaps there will be more tomorrow. Everyone who loves good books benefits this, surely, he added. The winning novel is fitting choice Australia's bicentennial year. It tells romance English gambler and Australian heiress who meet steamship's maiden voyage Australia mid-19th century. The story weaves Australian history its founding 1788 British immigrants. Panel chairman Michael Foot, writer and former leader opposition Labor Party, said judges agreed that entries this year had been exceptionally strong and that choosing last six novels was extremely difficult. We hope there will be no criticisms if there are, then people should start reading books themselves, Foot said. Carey was only non-Briton final six. The panel was unanimous, however, agreeing that standard other five novels was exceptionally high and this made their decision unusually interesting and unusually difficult. Ms. Byatt, who earlier this month won $43,000 Irish Times-Aer Lingus prize international fiction same work, has published five novels 1964. In Possession, she tells how two graduate students piece together relationship and lives two imaginary Victorian poets fragments their letters and retracing poets' journeys England and France. Her first novel, Shadow Sun, concerned efforts woman escape shadow her novelist father. A 1978 work, The Virgin Garden, makes allegorical allusions Shakespeare and other English literary geniuses tale play performed country house. Other finalists this year were 1979 Booker Prize winner Penelope Fitzgerald The Gate Angels, Irish novelist John McGahern's Amongst Women, Canadian-born Mordecai Richler's Solomon Gursky Was Here, Brian Moore's Lies Silence, and Beryl Bainbridge's An Awfully Big Adventure. Black Dogs Ian McEwan (Secker & Warburg Pounds 14.99). McEwan's fiction is uniquely disturbing - some would say deliberately offensive. He is novelist misanthropy. The Sri Lankan poet and novelist Ondaatje, who lives Canada, has followed 'in skin lion' extraordinary book four characters Tuscan villa closing months last war. The central metaphor is bombs - disposal of, and then Hiroshima. The 'English patient' is central mystery which others' stories orbit: he fell out sky flames; who is he? The FT review Saturday will hail it masterpiece. Daughters House Michele Roberts (Virago Pounds 14.99). The surprise contender because it is not published. Roberts comes Anglo-French Catholic background and this informs her new novel strong rural-Normandy atmosphere. Two cousins, one pious, one worldly. Shades Saint Therese Lisieux. Lots action kitchen; something is hidden cellar. Sacred Hunger Barry Unsworth (Hamish Hamilton Pounds 15.99). column5: A survey of Britain's exciting Booker Prize for fiction novels.
column6: Britain's Booker Prize for fiction is awarded yearly from a long list of novels narrowed down to a final six. A panel of judges selects the winner. Odds are given and literary insiders bet on which book will win. The winner receives a cash award and great prestige and sales.
column7: Britain's Booker Prize for fiction novels is similar to America's Pulitzer Prize and National Book awards but more excitement is associated with it. British publishers each submit three new titles. The total of around 100 books is narrowed down to a final six by a panel of learned judges after they have read all the novels. Odds are given with reviews, and literary insiders bet on which book will win the prize. The winner is announced at a yearly banquet.The Prize is administered by Book Trust, an educational charity, and sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business.
column8: America has the Pulitzer Prize for fiction and the National Book Awards but in terms of hoopla and excitement, there's nothing akin to Britain's Booker Prize. British publishers each submit three new titles for a total of approximately 100. There's a jury of judges, including writers, academics, politicians, editors and critics. Each juror reads every book and odds are given with reviews. The jurors then meet and select six finalists. Literary insiders bet on which book will win the Booker Prize. The winner is announced at a banquet in London's Elizabethan Guildhall, the seat the city's Lord Mayor, on the last Thursday in October. The authors can win up to $38,000. The event also guarantees great prestige and sales for the winner and brings the novel to public attention.Critics say the brouhaha distorts the annual fiction industry and the intense media hype does a disservice to other gifted but unlisted authors. On one recent occasion following heated deliberation between the judges, the chairman went public with a rousing condemnation of contemporary fiction.The Prize, first awarded in 1969, is administered by Book Trust, an educational charity promoting books. It is sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business.
column9: Booker Britain's Most Prestigious Literary Award. Competition Hot. Wagering Heavy.
column10: The Booker Prize was established in 1969 to honor the best fictionwork by a British or Commonwealth author. The Booker Company is thesponsor. It is now Britain's most prestigious literary award. Winnersreceive a substantial monetary award. Booker creates interest,motivates bettors, and boost book sales.
column11: The Booker Prize was established in 1969 to honor the best work of fiction by a British or Commonwealth author. It is sponsored by Booker, an international food and farming business. The Booker carries a substantial monetary award, and is now Britain's most prestigious fiction prize. Judges name six finalists, and later select the winner from those six. The competition creates great interest and motivates bettors. It also boosts book sales.Three of the recent winners now live in Britain or a Commonwealth country, but were born elsewhere. Only books written in English can be entered into Booker competition.
column12: The Booker Prize was first awarded in 1969. It honors the best work offiction by a British or Commonwealth author published in Britainduring the preceding 12 months.  The Booker is now the best known andmost prestigious fiction award in Britain. It carries a substantialmonetary prize, and is administered by Book Trust, an educationalcharity. Booker, an international food and farming business, sponsorsthe Prize.British publishers can submit up to three titles forconsideration. Each year a management team selects a new panel ofjudges. They announce a list of six finalists. Bookmakers establishbetting odds, and heavy betting ensues, most of it by literarypundits. Interest builds in the period leading up to the announcementof the winner, usually in October.  The hype that accompanies theselection boosts book sales.Penelope Lively's "Moon Tigers" won in 1987. Peter Carey's "Oscar andLucinda" won in 1988. Kazuo Ishiguro's "The Remains of the Day" won in1989. Antonia Byatt's "Possession" won in 1990. Michael Ondaatje's"The English Patient" won in 1992, and John Kelman's "How Late It Is,How Late" won in 1994. In 1994 the short-list was severely criticized,and a hypothetical 1894 Booker was contested.

column3: Tens thousands people chanting Freedom! Freedom! trekked Moslem saint's shrine Saturday campaign secession Kashmir India, witnesses and pro-separatist activists said. The deaths brought 109 number people killed Jan. 20 latest secessionist violence and government crackdown. Meanwhile, president Pakistan state Kashmir said interview Saturday that Kashmiris there had begun smuggling arms border Moslem insurgents fighting independence India. President Abdul Qayyum, speaking reporter who traveled Pakistan's Kashmir, said people his state also had been sheltering insurgents India launched military crackdown its state Jammu-Kashmir last month. In India's Kashmir, 600-year-old shrine Shiekh Nuruddin Wali Charift Sharief, 20 miles northwest Srinagar, became sea humanity Moslem men, women and children poured Srinagar and nearby towns. Vehicles stopped 10 miles shrine people thronged roads, said witnesses, who spoke condition anonymity. Supporters militants said they went shrine seek saint's blessings liberate Kashmir India. At least six fights broke out when people refused comply, said witnesses who spoke condition anonymity. On Friday, least 200,000 people marched office United Nations Military Observers Group Srinagar, demanding plebiscite Kashmir, police said. Witnesses claimed that more 600,000 people took part. The U.N. group is posted maintain cease-fire line drawn Indian- and Pakistani-held Kashmir 1948-49 war region. In Srinagar, suspected Moslem militants shot and killed Ashok Kumar, Hindu government employee, witnesses said, also speaking condition anonymity. Kumar was suspected be police informer. India routinely accuses Pakistan arming, training and supporting militants. The government Islamabad denies charge says Kashmiri people have right self-determination. Leading national parties decided Wednesday send high-powered delegation Srinagar, according Press Trust India news agency. It not name members, it said they would go Thursday. A joint statement meeting said their ideological and political differences, (the parties) were one defending unity and integrity country, news agency reported. The attacks came government claims that security forces arrested least 12 leaders Moslem group Hezbul Mujahedeen. Jagmohan said militants, Srinagar and border towns Baramulla and Kupwara, have been arrested Sunday. Hezbul Mujahedeen is one 30 militant groups fighting secession. It is believed second most powerful independence group Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. We are going hit hard anti-national elements, there is no way they can get away what they are doing, Jagmohan said. It may take month, six months, maybe year, ultimately these anti-national elments are going be neutralized. Jagmohan, Hindu, was appointed state governor Jammu-Kashmir Jan. 18 attempt government control unrest. Kashmir has been problem more four decades 1947 partition British colonial India predominantly Moslem Pakistan and mostly Hindu India. Jammu-Kashmir, then princely state, chose merge India. Pakistan protested, claiming territory because its predominantly Moslem population. The two countries have twice gone war territory. The Kashmir portion Jammu-Kashmir is mostly Moslem, while southern Jammu segment is predominantly Hindu. Overall, 65 percent state's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make 12 percent India's 880 million people and Hindus account 82 percent. Exotic Kashmir, tourist paradise houseboat hotels and Mogul gardens whose name English made cashmere, has become war zone separatism and religious enmity. Military jeeps carry senior government officials and civil servants Srinagar these dangerous days, soldiers and paramilitary troopers try stop campaign violence Moslem separatists Kashmir Valley. Intelligence officer M.K. Kaul commands one jeeps. At beginning trip city 1 million people, he turned four soldiers jeep's rear seats and ordered: Check your weapons. Be ready fire. Kaul settled front seat, 9mm pistol his right hand. These are bad days, he murmured. These die-hard terrorists can attack anywhere. To his men, he said: Shoot them if you see them. On Monday, around-the-clock curfew was lifted 5 a.m. noon and stores opened crowds customers. Soldiers sandbagged bunkers, armed light machine guns, guarded main intersections. A spokesman Jammu-Kashmir state government said situation was peaceful and absolutely normal Srinagar, state's largest city. At least 72 people have been killed crackdown began Jan. 20 effort curb attacks government officials and buildings. Most dead have been Moslem militants shot Indian troops. We are neither fighting war nor trying suppress any popular movement, said Jagmohan, governor Jammu-Kashmir, only state predominantly Hindu India Moslem majority. We are fighting handful terrorists who are determined create law and order problem, said Jagmohan, Hindu reputation toughness. Other officials Kashmir say privately situation is critical, perhaps most serious threat India has faced 42 years independence Britain. It looks everyone here has turned fundamentalist firm belief that day is not far when they will become independent, state police officer said. Kashmir was separate kingdom, ruled Hindu maharajah, when Britain relinquished colonial rule Aug. 15, 1947, and subcontinent was partitioned religious lines India and Pakistan. The Hindu king opted join India, not Pakistan, and dispute Kashmir has exacerbated relations since. Pakistan took western part Kashmir and India eastern. Each accused other forcible occupation. They have fought wars Kashmir and border question remains unresolved. U.N. observers are stationed truce line and two sides occasionally trade gunfire. Officials will not say how many reinforcements have been sent Kashmir Valley Jan. 20, reports various sources indicate 30,000-and 40,000 soldiers and paramilitary troops have been deployed. It is valley's heavily Moslem population that tilts sectarian scale Jammu-Kashmir state. Of state's nearly 6 million people, 64 percent are Moslems and 32 percent Hindus.
