column5: Indian government battles Muslim insurgents in Jammu-Kashmir on Pakistani border.
column6: The Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir is the scene of continuing violence between the government and Muslim insurgents who are seeking to establish an independent nation.  More the 1,000 have been killed since January.  Since 1947, predominately Islamic Pakistan and Hindu-majority India have fought twice over this Muslim-majority region.
column7: The Indian government has been fighting Muslim insurgents in the state of Jammu-Kashmir for the last seven months.  More than 1,000 people have been killed.  India (predominately Hindu) and Pakistan (predominately Islamic) have fought two wars over Kashmir since the nations were established in 1947.  Jammu-Kashmir is 62 percent Muslim and the insurgents want an independent nation.  Violence is occurring primarily near Srinagar, the capital, and along the border with Pakistan.  India claims the insurgents are being trained and armed in Pakistan.  Pakistan denies these charges.  The two nations recently exchanged fire, but both say there is no cause for concern.
column8: Fighting has broken out sporadically in the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir since January 20.  At least 1,034 people had been killed by late August.  The Indian government is battling Muslim insurgents seeking the formation of an independent, neutral, nation.  India (predominately Hindu) and Pakistan (predominately Islamic) have fought two wars over Kashmir since the nations were established in 1947.  Jammu-Kashmir is 62 percent Muslim.  Insurgent tactics have included bombings, kidnappings, killings of suspected police informers, ambushes of police vehicles, and attacks on police installations.  Large demonstrations have been held in Jammu-Kashmir and on the Pakistani border.  Indian tactics have include retaliatory fire, arresting and killing insurgent leaders, 24-hour curfews, disrupting and firing on demonstrations, and interfering with funerals of dead insurgents.  The state is now governed directly from New Delhi.In August, India increased border forces and operations and killed 80 infiltrators, claiming the insurgents are being trained and armed in Pakistan.  Pakistan denies these charges but says it does support the Muslims' crusade for "self-determination."  The Prime Minister of Pakistan has sought the support of other Islamic nations.  The two nations have exchanged fire on several occasions, but both say there is no cause for concern.
column9: Moslem separatists exacerbate Kashmir situation; India and Pakistan tradecharges
column10: Moslem separatists in Jammu-Kashmir have turned to violence hoping to gainseparation from India.  Over 1,000 have died in the violence and repressionfrom government forces.  India and Pakistan hurl accusations and somebullets at each other but claim the situation is localized and not serious.
column11: India and Pakistan have feuded over Jammu-Kashmir since the subcontinentwas divided in 1947.  It is India's only predominately Moslem state with 64%of its five million people Moslem.  Moslem separatists began a campaign ofviolence in Jammu-Kashmir hoping initially to lead to union with Pakistanbut later for independence.  Indian authorities began a crackdown in January1990, and by summer, over a thousand people died.  India accused Pakistan ofarming and training the insurgents, a charge Pakistan denied.  Despiteincidences of soldiers firing across cease-fire lines, the two countriessaid the situation was local and not serious.
column12: Kashmir had been a separate kingdom ruled by a Hindu when Britainrelinquished colonial rule of the Indian subcontinent in 1947.   It waspartitioned on religious lines into India and Pakistan and Kashmir's Hinduking opted to be part of India.  The Jammu-Kashmir state is India's onlypredominately Moslem state with 64% of the state's 5 million people Moslem.Jammu-Kashmir has been a contentious issue between India and Pakistan fromthe beginning and the two have fought over it.  In 1990, separatistelements, most prominently the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, began acampaign of violence, including kidnapping, bombings, and assassinations.Initially, the Moslem separatists wanted to become part of Pakistan, butlater hoped to become an independent nation.  The Indian government began acrackdown in January of that year, imposing curfews and retaliating toinsurgent attacks.   By summer, police actions and separatists' violence hadresulted in over a thousand deaths.   India and Pakistan hurled charges ateach other with India claiming that Pakistan trained and armed theinsurgents, a claim that Pakistan denied.  Both nations sent troops to theborder area astride the cease-fire line and some shots were exchanged.Despite the tensions, both countries downplayed the incidents as beinglocalized and not serious.

column5: Death of Robert Maxwell raises questions of economic dealings.
column6: Economic confusion surrounds the publishing empire of Robert Maxwell following his death. Maxwell was found dead off the Canary Islands, apparently after having fallen overboard. Maxwell, along with his two sons, Kevin and Ian, and Michael Stone, a Maxwell executive, apparently were involved in the illegal transfer of funds.
column7: Economic confusion surrounds the mysterious death of publishing magnate Robert Maxwell. Maxwell, who put together a publishing empire following his immigration to Britain in 1940, was found dead off the coast of the Canary Islands after apparently having fallen overboard from his yacht. There are allegations that Maxwell, along with two of his sons, Kevin and Ian, and a senior executive in several Maxwell corporations, Michael Stoney, were involved in the illegal transfer of funds to help his publishing empire fend off debt. The scheme used Swiss trusts and a number of institutions, including the U.S. investment bank, Goldman Sachs.
column8: Robert Maxwell has been described as the Citizen Kane of his time. The mysterious death of this larger than life individual on November 5 has left the economic affairs of Maxwell Communications Corporation and Mirror Group Newspapers is a state of confusion. Maxwell was born in Czechoslovakia and immigrated to Britain in 1940 to escape the Holocaust. He put together and personally ran world-wide publishing empire that included Macmillan Publishing House in New York, Britain's Daily mirror, the Daily Record and the European and British Printing Company, and communications Corp., Britain's largest printing company. Improprieties have been alleged in the handling of funds which involve not only Robert Maxwell, but two of his sons, Kevin and Ian, as well as Michael Stoney, an executive in several Maxwell companies. At issue is the alleged improper transfer of funds in an attempt to handle his publishing empire's crushing debts. Among the interests named in the transfer of funds to two Swiss trusts, is the U.S. investment firm Goldman Sachs. Maxwell also is accused of using MCC in an effort to raise funds by making late payments on the foreign market. In doing so, MCC in effect gave itself an unauthorized loan.
column9: British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell and sons guilty of financial fraud.
column10: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell died in 1991 in the waters off Canary Island while on vacation. His sons Kevin and Ian took over the Maxwell business but were soon found guilty along with their father of using illegal financial schemes and looting pension funds to pay off crushing debts.
column11: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell, owner of the Mirror Group Newspaper Ltd. of Britain and publisher of Britain's Daily Mirror and the New York Daily News, died in 1991 in the waters off Canary Island while on vacation.  His sons Kevin and Ian took over the business but were soon implicated along with their father in an illegal scheme to deal with crushing debts. Allegedly, unauthorized loans were acquired by using a Maxwell company to buy currency in one financial center while promising, but often failing, to make payments to another center. Some repayments were made by looting pension funds.
column12: British media entrepreneur Robert Maxwell, publisher of Britain's Daily Mirror, bought the New York Daily News in 1990. He then planned to raise $448 million through the sale of shares in his Mirror Group Newspaper Ltd. of Britain. He bought Mirror Group in 1984 and turned it into one of Britain's most profitable newspaper groups.A year after the Daily News purchase, he was found dead in the waters off the Canary Island where he was vacationing on his yacht. Investigators say Maxwell siphoned money from his companies in an attempt to deal with crushing debts. Some $630 million was taken from his Mirror Group pension fund without authority. His sons Kevin and Ian, who took over the business, were investigated and found guilty for their knowledge of illegal schemes using two Swiss trusts, a private UK trust company and a US investment bank to support the Maxwell Communications Company (MCC). In a flurry of foreign exchange deals, the MCC would buy currency in one financial center promising, but often failing, to make payment in another center; thus getting an unauthorized loan. Some repayments were made by looting pension funds assets.

An Argentine supply ship that ran aground Antarctica sank Tuesday heavy seas and high winds, government said, and there was concern oil its hold could leak and damage environment. The sinking 400-foot Bahia Paraiso followed warnings U.S. National Science Foundation that unspoiled Antarctic could face ecological disaster if 250,000 gallons diesel fuel ship were spill. No injuries were reported sinking. Tourists and crew had been evacuated vessel, which was 600 miles south Cape Horn, tip South America. Salvage efforts had been hampered 50 mph winds. The double-hulled oceanographic ship sank 10 p.m., government news agency Telam said, citing navy communique. Telam not say whether ship broke or if diesel oil spilled when it went down. The depth water which ship sank was not immediately known. The ship had been carrying supplies including jet fuel, gasoline and canisters compressed gases Argentine Esperanza station tip Antarctic Peninsula, National Science Foundation said statement released Washington. The ship ran aground Saturday two miles Palmer Station, U.S. research facility Antarctic Peninsula, continent's tip. It sustained 35-foot-long gash its hull, and some 250,000 gallons diesel fuel began leaking, washing ashore Palmer station. The fuel killed some krill, tiny shrimp-like creature that is vital part Antarctic food chain, and has affected penguins, sea gulls and giant petrel birds, National Science Foundation statement said. There were no immediate details extent damage wildlife pristine surroundings. Agency spokesman Jack Renerie said Tuesday ship sank that leak, which was threatening penguins and other wildlife, had stopped. Scientists are concerned that some research search projects may already have been affected leak, foundation statement said. It said two Argentine salvage vessels were expected arrive Thursday or Friday. Before sinking, Argentine officials had discounted spill. Telam quoted Argentine navy sources saying: The fuel it carried, itself and Antarctic stations, was steel drums so spill is practically impossible. The 316 people ship when it ran aground, including 82 passengers and 234 crew members, were rescued power boats and taken Palmer Station. The passengers and most crew were taken cruise ship South Shetland Islands, which they were airlifted South American mainland Sunday. But 104 crewmen remain station, said Renerie. Because station is equipped only 40 people, food has been rationed two meals day, National Science Foundation statement said. Ballard said Thursday. During 90-minute news conference, Ballard described how he his ocean-crawling robot located Bismarck sitting upright and proud two weeks ago. Then American oceanographer, whose father was British background and whose mother was German heritage, addressed himself German people German. I am underwater explorer, not treasure hunter, he said, translating himself back English. We found no human remains. We touched nothing and took nothing. ... The future Bismarck is hands German people. He said he will disclose its exact location only Germany so Germans themselves can decide whether try raise ship, which sank battle May 27, 1941. Ballard, senior scientist Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution Massachusetts, said structural evidence satisfied him that Germans scuttled battleship rather trying surrender or allowing her be sent British fire. Only scuttled ships tend make it bottom one piece, Ballard said. It appears crew opened it its entire length. It was clearly flooded, stem stern. Maybe Germans didn't want it taken war prize, he added. It is known that two years earlier, Hitler ordered German pocket battleship Graf Spee scuttled it was cornered neutral port Montevideo, Uruguay, and attacked British ships. Hitler apparently wanted keep British learning secrets Graf Spee's construction and weapons. In 1941 battle, Bismarck's main guns were quickly knocked out and attacking British ships were out range her secondary guns, Ballard said, so its was helpless and taking hundreds hits  its sinking clearly inevitable. Rendered unsteerable torpedoes dropped tiny fabric-covered British biplanes, it was unable escape. Asked if German commander couldn't have surrendered ceasing fire, Ballard said fuzz battle fierce seas it would have been unlikely that British would have recognized that Germans were giving up. Again, he speculated, perhaps Germans not want ship's technologically advanced equipment fall British hands. The Bismarck was found Ballard more 15,000 feet water 600 miles west Brest, France. He said it was remarkably good shape, elegant, well preserved. Before battle, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill had left convoys unprotected and thrown all his capital ships pursuit ringing three-word command: Sink Bismarck! Of Bismarck's 2,200-man crew, only 115 survived. British ships picked 110 survivors left hundreds German sailors still icy waters spotting what might have been German U-boat. German vessels later rescued only five more survivors. The story has been recounted books, songs and movie. The sinking occurred only eight days Bismarck left Gdynia, Poland, her first operation. If unstopped, it could have posed critical threat convoys merchant shipping and undercut British morale time when England stood virtually alone combined German sea and air power. The British sent warship Hood Bismarck five days going sea Bismarck had sunk Hood three-minute engagement, loss all three vessel's crew 1,419. The Hood was symbol British sea power, and its loss stunned British public and war government and made sinking Bismarck mission crucial importance. Ballard said laws sea, Bismarck remains property German people. The sunken battleship was discovered and photographed same remote-controlled robot that Ballard used four years ago find wreck Titanic, British passenger liner that sank 1912 striking iceberg. Greek divers have plunged 162 feet Aegean Sea and back history, finding treasure-laden Turkish warship sunk Greek revolutionaries 1822. The remains wooden sailing ship were found island Chios eastern Aegean point where historical accounts place sinking Ottoman ship, according Peter Nicolaides, diver and salvage expert. The Bourloti Seimaz  or Explosives Invincible  was set afire and sunk Greek Admiral Constantine Kanaris revenge Turkish killing and looting Chios. Thousands islanders died Turkish raids, which shocked other nations and swung Western European countries Greek struggle independence Ottoman Empire. Greece won independence 1830. The French painter Eugene Delacroix produced famous picture, The Massacre Chios, based raids. It's incredible discovery, straight out history book we used read school War Independence, Nicolaides said interview Friday The Associated Press. Nicolaides, who heard wreck while teaching underwater archaeology course local divers last winter, started querying fishermen where their nets snagged seabed obstacles. He pinpointed wreck May 3, he said. When I dived, I found ships' timbers sticking out muddy seabed and dozens objects  Islamic cooking pots, cannon balls, candlestick, chalice Greek Orthodox church, he said. The ship was obviously crammed loot Chios. I think there may be gold and silver items well, he said. I also saw what I recognized human bones, he added. He said wreckage indicated vessel was least 100 feet length. According historians, more 1,000 people  including 400 Greek captives  were ship when Kanaris staged his attack early hours June 7, 1822. The Greek admiral sailed nearby island Psara, towing boat stuffed explosives. Its pointed bow was rammed mouth cannon Bourloti Seimaz and fuse lit. The Ottoman commander, Admiral Kara Ali, was killed blast that split ship. Kanaris and his crew Greeks escaped. This is very significant, very emotive find, coming this particular period history, said George Papathanassopoulos, Culture Ministry's adviser marine archaeology. Papathanassopoulos said 162-foot water depth site will make investigation difficult underwater archaeology rarely is attempted depths 113 feet, he said, This is ship that must be explored. Nicolaides said he hoped it would be possible tap American and Turkish expertise excavate wreck international project. American experts Institute Nautical Archaeology Texas A & M University, working cooperation Turkish divers, have pioneered underwater excavation Turkish Aegean coast. Greek marine archaeologists focus locating and surveying historic wrecks scattered Aegean and rarely carry out excavations. Ferries are safest vessels afloat. But, tragic sinking Estonia loss more 800 lives demonstrates, when they do go toll human life can be high. As ferries increase size, so numbers board risk mechanical failure or crew error go up. The move roll-on roll-off ferries vehicle decks which run entire length vessel has increased risk that, once sea penetrates hold bow doors or gash ship's side, it can lead vessel capsizing. The United Nations International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and its members, ship-owning nations, have devoted much thought two decades ship safety. But sinking Estonia should lead new review ferry safety. Particularly worrying are eyewitness reports which suggest that water penetrated bow doors manner reminiscent sinking Herald Free Enterprise 1987. Unlike Herald, Estonia appears have had its doors closed, ro-ros are undoubtedly very vulnerable water penetration. Any review ferry safety should focus three main issues. First subject ferry design should be reconsidered. Additional stability could be provided addition sponsons, stabilising bulges which project ship's side just water line. Greater resistance influx water could be obtained installing moveable barriers or bulkheads break large car decks. These proposals were looked British government wake sinking Herald Free Enterprise. It calculated that it would cost Pounds 70m and Pounds 85m improve standards 57 vessels UK ferry fleet, further Pounds 22m extra annual running costs. Higher costs would inevitably lead higher fares - unwelcome ferry operators when, short cross-Channel routes, they face competition Channel tunnel. But difficulty pushing fare rises would be nothing damaging ferry companies another disaster. Second, IMO and national governments must look closely how improve enforcement existing regulations. The IMO has been trying move enforcement its agenda, it depends good will and professionalism governments and shipowners. Third, IMO should be given support national governments its campaign, launched yesterday, improve crew training. Much regulation recent years has concentrated improving ship and its equipment. Above all, if new regulation does turn out be necessary, it must be introduced speedily. As things stand, it can take years changes are ratified enough governments give them force. The European Union, which Sweden and Finland are getting ready join, could take lead speeding process. Ship safety is not, course, just issue ferry sector. Five (small) ferries were lost last year, according Lloyd's Register. But this figure pales insignificance compared 96 general cargo ships and 12 tankers which also went down. When cargo vessel third-world crew goes distant ocean, very little attention is paid. If loss relatively modern passenger vessel European waters can make shipping safety higher priority governments and public, this will be some small compensation loss life Estonia. Two sailors were missing Monday evening 652-foot freighter en route Greece apparently sank rough seas 400 miles southeast Cape Cod. Twenty-three crew members were rescued. The 23 sailors Star Alexandria were found lifeboat and picked merchant ship Ravenscraig, Coast Guard Petty Officer Randy Midgett said New York. They're all good shape, some minor cuts and scrapes, Midgett said. The two missing sailors were believed be life raft, which was object hunt Monday evening 950-foot Ravenscraig and five Navy and Coast Guard search planes, officials said. The Ravenscraig's crew spotted second life raft, it turned out be empty. The cause sinking was not immediately known, officials said. The Star Alexandria had been en route Athens, Greece, New York load cement when it began taking water 12-foot seas and winds 35 mph, Midgett said. The first mayday call went out 9:05 a.m. A Coast Guard jet air station Cape Cod and C-130 plane Elizabeth City, N.C., converged ship. The lifeboat was spotted noon. The C-130 was able drop radio water boat carrying 23 crew members and they were able establish communications, Midgett said. About four hours later, they were rescued Ravenscraig. The Star Alexandria was not spotted, and was presumed be sinking or sunk, Midgett said. Visibility rough seas was five eight miles Monday afternoon. The Star Alexandria was built 1966, and was registered England. It was designed carry bulk freight, and was owned Caribene Investments Ltd. Gibraltar, according Bureau Veritas, Paris-based shipping registry. The Ravenscraig had been bound England, its destination its rescue mission was not immediately known.
column5: Maritime Losses Continue. Estonia Lost With 800 Aboard. Bismarck Found
column6: Three freighters, two ocean-going yachts, a supply ship, a fishing vessel, and a ferry carrying 800 passengers were some of the maritime losses between 1888 and 1994.The German battleship Bismarck, scuttled off France in 1941, was located in 1989. A Turkish vessel, sunk in 1822, was located in 1988.
column7: Freighters sank off Cape Cod in 1989, and in the North Sea in 1988. A 1989 Austrian scandal grew out of the 1977 sinking of the Lucona. In 1989 an Argentine supply ship sank in Antarctica. In 1994 a Korean fishing vessel was scuttled while fishing illegally near Argentina. The Ostwind, once Hitler's yacht, was purposely sunk off Florida. An American pleasure boat was sunk by aggressive whales. In 1994 the ferry Estonia sank with 800 aboard.The German battleship Bismarck, scuttled in 1989, was located in 1989. A Turkish vessel, sunk in 1822, was found in 1988.
column8: Articles published between 1988 and 1994 demonstrate the widely diverse circumstances that surround the sinking of ocean-going vessels.Some articles addressed the locating of vessels sunk many years earlier. In May 1988 divers located a Turkish ship sunk by the Greek Navy in 1822. The Bismarck, Germany's most powerful battleship was scuttled off France in May 1941, and found in June 1944.The freighter Star of David went down in rough seas off Cape Cod on 17 April 1989. High winds prevailed when a Finnish freighter sank in the North Sea in September 1988. A 1989 scandal that involved Austrian politicians grew out of the mysterious sinking of the freighter Lucona in the Indian Ocean 12 years earlier.The Ostwind, a yacht built for Hitler, came to an ignominious end off the coast of Florida. In the same month whales attacked and sank the American pleasure boat Sibonay off Costa Rica.In January 1989 an Argentine supply ship sank two miles off the Antarctic Peninsula. A Korean vessel, fishing illegally in Argentine waters, was scuttled in May 1994 when apprehended by the Argentine Coast Guard.Eight hundred lives were lost when the ferry Estonia sank in 1994.
column9: Many causes responsible for sending ships to bottom of sea.
column10: Many reasons for ships sinking exist.  Ships that run aground from unseenhazards often sink.  Naval battles generally result in ships being sunk.Faulty design and rough seas may cause a ship to sink.  A crew may scuttleits ship to avoid capture or to conceal illegal activity.
column11: Severe weather at sea, faulty ship design, unseen obstacles, and hostileaction are some of the many reasons that ships sink.  At times, ships aresunk deliberately, by a dishonest owner in an insurance scam or by a navalcrew in wartime to foil an enemy or by a crew to conceal illegal activities.Loss of life very often accompanies a ship=B9s sinking.  Efforts to locatesunken ships are undertaken to determine why the ship went down and,sometimes, in the hope of recovering treasure.  Ships sinking are notuncommon events. In 1993, over 100 vessels went under.
column12: Ships sink for many reasons.  Many because of severe weather conditions atsea, some because they run aground, some because of design faults, some byhostile action, and some smaller vessels sink after encounters with marineanimals. Sometimes a ship sinking is deliberate.  Dishonest owners have sunktheir ships in order to collect insurance money.  Crews have deliberatelysunk their ship to prevent it from falling into enemy hands during wartimeor at other times to conceal evidence of illegal activity.  Older orderelict ships often serve to help establish a coral reef or become amemorial when sunk.  Many ships sink each year.  In 1993, 96 general cargoships, 12 tankers, and 5 ferries went to the bottom.Loss of life, sometimes heavy, usually occurs when a ship sinks.  A ferrysinking in 1994 caused more than 800 deaths.  Sea explorers search forsunken vessels to determine exactly where and often why they sank.  Somehope to recover treasures.Historic events have resulted from ships sinking.  In the 18th century, aship sinking figured in the Greek struggle for independence from the OttomanEmpire.  In the 20th century, two high Austrian government officialsresigned because of a scandal, which involved the sinking of a ship.

column3: John G. Tower has fallen, sky has not. For all forecasts dire results if Senate blocked Tower's path Pentagon, business is proceeding usual. That's over, he said 24 hours Tower defeat. That's history. And now we are going go forward. He told his Georgia constituents that Tower rejection would not hurt Bush's leadership. In Washington, `triumphs' and `setbacks' are short-lived, Nunn said, and that's particularly true president. While endeavoring look statesmanlike, Sen. Nunn leaned moderate Democrats who would otherwise have supported Tower. Sen. Nunn made campaign personal, says Mr. Tower -- vote me or vote him. Most Democrats, end, went Sen. Nunn. What was all this about? Morality? Mr. Tower suggests instead that Sen. When media retailed lurid and unsubstantiated stories, Sen. Nunn pursed his lips Georgia Sunday-school superintendent and suggested that drunken Mr. Tower might accidentally press nuclear button. John Warner, Republican, is depicted falling all himself stay good Sen. Nunn. "I don't so much resent my rejection Senate," Mr. Tower insists, "as way it was done." "Tower, you were lynched," Mike Wallace, CBS correspondent, told him. Worse yet, lynch mob remains large. --- Mr. Murchison is senior columnist Dallas Morning News. The Democratic-controlled Senate today rejected nomination former Texas Sen. column5: Former Texas Senator John Tower killed in plane crash.
column6: Former Texas Senator John Tower was killed in the crash of a commuter plane off the coast of Georgia. Senator Tower had been President Bush's nominee for Secretary of Defense. The Senate rejected the nomination following allegations of problems with alcohol and inappropriate dealings with defense contractors.
column7: Former Texas Senator John Tower and his daughter were killed in the crash of a commuter plane on Sea Island, off the coast of Georgia. Senator Tower had been President Bush's nominee for Secretary of defense, but the nomination was rejected by the Senate on the recommendation of the Senate Armed Services Committee. This was only the ninth time in history that a cabinet nominee has been rejected. The committee recommended rejection after hearing allegations about Tower's use of alcohol and his inappropriate behavior towards women. The committee also questioned his dealings with defense contractors after Tower gave contradictory testimony.
column8: Former Texas Senator John Tower was killed in a commuter plane crash on Sea Island, off the coast of Georgia. The crash, which killed everyone on board, also took the life of his daughter, Marian. Tower was recently the center of controversy when his nomination for Secretary of Defense was rejected by the Senate Armed Forces Committee and the full Senate. Tower became only the ninth nominee in history to be rejected. He also was the first nominee ever to be rejected so early in the term of a new presidency. Tower's rejection followed allegations of problems with alcohol. Tower admitted that he had been a heavy drinker in the 70s but that he has since limited his drinking to a glass of wine with dinner. Tower, twice divorced, also was accused of inappropriate behavior towards women. The Senate Armed Services Committee also called into question his contradictory testimony on his dealings with defense contractors. Tower told the committee that his advice to British Aerospace was limited to civil aviation matters while in a 1987 deposition written for his second divorce, he said he advised the company on selling certain systems to the defense department.
column9: Ex-Senator John Tower, rejected for Defense Secretary, killed in plane crash
column10: Former senator John Tower's bid to become Defense Secretary failed on a53-47 vote in the Senate.  Tower's drinking, womanizing, and questionabledealings with defense contractors led to his defeat.  No lasting damage torelations between the Senate and the president are expected.  Tower waskilled in a 1991 plane crash.
column11: President Bush picked former senator John Tower of Texas to be Secretary ofDefense.  His choice was popular with Senate Republicans and he was expectedto win easy confirmation.  However, questions arose regarding Tower=B9s moralcharacter, heavy drinking, womanizing and lucrative dealings with defensecontractors.  Tower said earlier problems with alcohol were behind him, butthere were indications that they still existed. The Democratic controlledArmed Services Committee voted 11-9 against recommending Tower. The fullSenate rejected Tower 53-47 with one Republican voting against him and threeDemocrats for him.   John Tower and his daughter were killed in a planecrash in 1991.
column12: John Tower of Texas served in the US Senate for 24 years, retiring in 1985.President-elect George Bush named him to be Secretary of Defense.  Justbefore Senate Armed Services Committee confirmation hearings began, Towerhad surgery for the removal of a benign colon polyp.  Initially, members ofthe committee and early witnesses had praise for the former senator.However, later testimony suggested that Tower was a heavy drinker andwomanizer.  Tower conceded that years earlier he had problems with alcohol,but said those days were behind him.  Questions continued to surface thatthose days were not that long ago.  The FBI was lax in investigating thoserecent incidents.  An editorial supporting Tower conceded that he hadearlier "boozed it up and fooled around" but said that recent charges didnot have substance.  Tower's testimony that he had not dealt in defensematters when on the payroll of British Aerospace contradicted an earlierdeposition in which he said he did just that.  The committee, controlled byDemocrats, voted 11-9 against recommending rejection of Tower.  The fullSenate rejected Tower 53-47, with one Republican against him and threeDemocrats for him.

column3: President Bush is expected name female career diplomat U.S. ambassador Nicaragua that country prepares new era President-elect Violeta Chamorro, according informed sources. Baker III Managua post, and approval is considered 99.9 percent certain, one source said. The United States and Nicaragua have not had ambassadors each other's capitals July 1988. Mozambique has moderated its policies and is now U.S. government's list countries Marxist rule. Mrs. Chamorro faces demanding challenges reviving Nicaragua's bankrupt economy and achieving national reconciliation long years warfare. The United States has had no ambassador Nicaragua July 1988. At time, Sandinista government expelled Ambassador Richard Melton and seven embassy grounds they were interfering country's internal affairs. The Reagan administration retaliated expelling eight Nicaraguan envoys Washington, including Ambassador Carlos Tunnermann. Shlaudeman, who has served ambassador Argentina, Peru, Brazil and Venezuela, is premier State Department specialist Latin America and is expected win easy Senate confirmation. In addition his ambassadorial posts, Shlaudeman was top Latin America aide President Ford mid-1970s and diplomatic trouble-shooter Central America President Reagan. The U.S. official said Sen. When Wells was nominated be ambassador Mozambique late 1986, Helms and his colleagues blocked her appointment 11 months. Spiers, veteran U.S. diplomat, will be new undersecretary-general General Assembly affairs, top-ranking American post world body, U.N. officials said Tuesday. Spiers was ambassador Pakistan 1981-83 and has served ambassador Bahamas and Turkey. He replaces Joseph Verner Reed, banker who served post 1987 leaving last winter become chief protocol United States. Although Spiers' nomination undersecretary-general Political and General Assembly Affairs and Secretariat Services had been open secret months, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced it was effective Tuesday. Spiers, 64, is career foreign service officer, most recently serving undersecretary state management 1983. Spiers has been member U.S. delegation United Nations; was director political affairs U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency; and was director NATO Affairs State Department. From 1966-69, Spiers was counselor political affairs U.S. Embassy London. In 1969, he became assistant secretary State charge department's Bureau Political-Military Affairs. When Bahamas became independent Britain 1973, Spiers became first U.S. ambassador that nation. He became charge d'affaires London 1974, and was minister U.S. Embassy there 1977, when he was appointed ambassador Turkey. In 1980 he returned State Department director Intelligence and Research, and was appointed ambassador Pakistan 1981. Joseph B. Sarbanes says appointments are larding diplomatic corps amateurs rewarded purely political services. Political throwaways, Sarbanes calls them. I think time has come, very frankly, get money merry-go-round and ask some very difficult questions, essentially when extensive political contributions are going be sufficient basis gain ambassadorial nomination, Sarbanes told committee last month. It's not true every instance, most these cases you seem have be $100,000 mark order make consideration list, Sarbanes said. Sarbanes says he is not political ambassadors such, noting that many them compiled distinguished records. It is not political ambassadors that are problem, Sarbanes said. It is ambassadors qualifications. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today endorsed nomination Michigan Republican activist Peter F. Secchia ambassador Italy, panel's chairman said he feared Secchia might embarrass United States because his penchant making gross remarks. The committee's vote was 13-0 favor Secchia, former Republican national committeeman Michigan and lumber industry executive. The chairman, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., voted present, meaning they took no position. Pell inserted hearing record newspaper accounts containing distasteful specifics Mr. Secchia's remarks. At his confirmation hearing earlier this month, Secchia pledged be far more careful diplomat his use colorful language he had been his different role political organizer and enthusiast. But Pell said he was unpersuaded. Tact and careful speech are hallmarks successful diplomats, Pell said. Mr. Secchia has demonstrated that he would bring qualities position ambassador Italy. Italian friends mine telephoned me Rome, aghast prospect having Mr. Secchia represent United States their country, chairman said. I believe that this nomination is mistake, and all likelihood Mr. Secchia will be embarrasment administration and United States, Pell said. But he said that Secchia is president's choice he would not try block nomination or delay action it. President Bush has named career diplomat Deane Hinton ambassador Panama, White House announced Tuesday. Hinton, currently ambassador Costa Rica, replaces Ambassador Arthur H. Davis, who was recalled Bush protest what administration considered stealing Panamanian elections last May Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush sent Davis back Panama City Dec. 20 invasion Panama U.S. forces and installation Guillermo Endara president. Independent observers mostly concluded Endara had won elections hefty margin. Bush named Hinton recess appointment because Congress is not session. That means Hinton can serve end next year he must go Senate confirmation. The appointment 66-year-old Hinton, his long expierience Latin American issues, is seen signal importance Bush is placing restoring normal relations Panama. Those relations steadily deteriorated United States indicted Noriega, once ally particularly U.S. intelligence community, drug trafficking charges Florida. Hinton has been ambassador Costa Rica 1987. Before that he was ambassador Pakistan 1983 1987, and ambassador El Salvador 1981 1983. He was assistant secretary state economic and business affairs 1979 1981, and that U.S. representative 12-nation European Community, headquartered Brussels, State Department adviser economic affairs, and director and economic counselor State Department's Agency economic Development Chile and Guatemala. Davis, former State Department consultant and former ambassador Paraguay, was sent Panama President Reagan 1986. Bush wanted name his ambassador and time was appropriate installation new government Panama, said one administration official. Officials described Hinton experienced Latin America hand and good person have place volatile developments South American country. On Capitol Hill, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called Hinton highly qualified post because his wide-ranging experience and expertise Central America. However, Mitchell said he hoped Bush would send appointment Senate Congress convenes Jan. 23 nature recess appointment.
column5: Bush ambassadorial nominees include veteran diplomats and big campaign contributors
column6: Veteran diplomats nominated by Bush as ambassadors included James Lilley (China), John Negroponte (Mexico), Deane Hinton (Panama), Harry Shlaudeman (Nicaragua), Thomas Pickering (India), Wesley Egan (Jordan), and Edward Perkins (UN). Bush also nominated campaign contributors Joseph Zappala (Spain), Marvin Semble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), Joseph Gildenhorn (Switzerland), and Peter Secchia (Italy).
column7: Bush nominated veteran diplomats James Lilley (formerly CIA) to China, John Negroponte (who helped direct CIA aid to Contras) to Mexico, Deane Hinton to Panama,  Harry Shlaudeman to Nicaragua (over Melissa Wells), Thomas Pickering to India, and Wesley Egan to Jordan (interpreted there as signaling Jordanian importance to the US).  Edward Perkins became UN ambassador. Nominees Joseph Zappala (Spain), Marvin Semble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), and Joseph Gildenhorn (Switzerland) were said qualified only by large campaign contributions, and nomination of loudmouth Peter Secchia (Italy) was called a mistake. Other nominations included Shirley Temple Black (Czechoslovakia), Thomas Melady (Vatican),  Keith Brown (Denmark), and William Howard Taft IV (NATO).
column8: Bush ambassadorial nominations of veteran diplomats included JamesLilley (former CIA officer) to China, John Negroponte (who asambassador to Honduras helped direct CIA aid to Nicaraguan rebels) toMexico, Deane Hinton (former ambassador to El Salvador and Costa Rica)to Panama following the US invasion, Harry Shlaudeman (formerambassador to Argentina, Peru, Brazil, and Venezuela) to Nicaragua(over early favorite Melissa Wells, who had no Latin Americanexperience and might have faced confirmation delays), and ThomasPickering (experienced in delicate situations concerning Iraq and ElSalvador) to nuclear power India. Jordan saw the appointment there ofseasoned ambassador Wesley Egan as a signal of Jordan's importance tothe US.  At the UN, Foreign Service Director Edward Perkins replacedPickering as ambassador and Ronald Spiers got the top-ranked Americanpost. The ambassadorial nominations of Joseph Zappala (Spain), MarvinSemble (Australia), Della Newman (New Zealand), and Joseph Gildenhorn(Switzerland) were approved despite charges that their onlyqualifications were large campaign contributions. Senate ForeignRelations Chairman Claiborne Pell called the nomination of PeterSecchia as ambassador to Italy a mistake because of his bigmouth. Routinely approved nominations included Shirley Temple Black(Czechoslovakia), Thomas Melady (Vatican), Keith Brown (Denmark), andWilliam Howard Taft IV (NATO).
column9: President's ambassador selections get Senate committee approval, some narrowly
column10: Most of President Bush's ambassadorial nominees won easy approval in senatecommittee hearings.  A few, however, faced opposition from Democrats incommittee who believed they were nominated only because of largecontributions to the Republican.  But all were finally approved.
column11: Some of President Bush's nominees for ambassadorships have been selected asa reward for large money contributions to the Republican Party, according toDemocratic senators, and some retired diplomats consider a few not to bequalified.   These nominees faced strong questioning from the Democratsduring committee hearings but did manage to get a slim approval from thecommittee.  Conservative senators objected to two of Bush's selections.Most of the president's picks won easy approval.  Two of Bush's picksreceived highly favorable reaction: a Latin American expert for ambassadorto Nicaragua, and the naming of Thomas Pickering, a well-known diplomat, toIndia.
column12: Senate confirmation hearings for President Bush's nominees forambassadorships have shown mixed results for the administration.  Somenominees like Shirley Temple Black the designated ambassador toCzechoslovakia, sailed through the process. The nominees for Spain,Switzerland, Australia, and New Zealand faced strong questioning duringSenate committee hearings but were eventually slimly approved.  Democratsand retired diplomats believed that three of the nominees had no realqualifications but were picked because of large money contributions to theRepublican Party. Democrats also had concern about the nominee to beambassador to Italy.   Senator Jesse Helms and other conservatives objectedto one nominee because he was a Democrat and were thought likely to havesuch strong objections to another that her name was withdrawn.  That womanwas initially picked to be ambassador to Nicaragua since that country was toinstall a woman as president but the potential objections led to a seasonedLatin American expert being named.  The administration picked ThomasPickering, the ambassador to the UN to be ambassador to India.  Thisselection of a well-known diplomat underscores the administration concernregarding the Indian subcontinent where India and Pakistan, both now nuclearcapable, continue to feud over Kashmir.

column5: Strong Himalayan Quake Kills 704 in Nepal; 277 in India
column6: Sunday's strong, Himalayan earthquake, triggered landslides and collapsed houses. Authorities say 704 died in Nepal, 277 in India. Monsoon rains and aftershocks hampered search and recovery efforts throughout the quake area. Flooding is possible.Of Nepal' 157 Peace Corps volunteers, 154 have been found safe. India has no Peace Corp workers.
column7: The official death toll in Sunday's pre-dawn Himalayan earthquake is 981, 704 in Nepal and 277 in India. Many, especially in Dharan, Nepal, died when brick houses that used rain loosened mud between the bricks, collapsed in the 6.5 (Richter scale) quake. Bihar, India, where authorities say 200 died, is also threatened by flooding.  Monsoon rains and aftershocks hampered relief efforts and the search for victims throughout the quake area. Of Nepal's 157 Peace Corps volunteers, 154 have been found safe. India has no Peace Corp workers. The U.S., Britain, and the international community are sending aid to the devastated area.
column8: On Friday, Nepal updated its death toll from Sunday's Himalayan earthquake to 704 as reports arrived from remote area. In India, the official death toll rose to 277, 200 of which were in Bihar, but the press and others claim as many as 1500 may have perished. Bihar is also threatened by flooding from swollen rivers.The quake, measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale, struck at 4:54 a.m. (local). According to Nepal's Department of Geology, it was centered near Udayapur, Nepal. Monsoon rains, overflowing rivers, submerged bridges and roads and aftershocks hampered relief efforts and the search for victims in throughout the quake area.In Dharan, Nepal, over 131 bodies were found, most in collapsed houses that had used mud, loosened by rain, between the bricks. Karna Hyanju, a former Nepalese legislator, however, did not die in the quake. He was killed after being accused of distributing relief supplies only to his supporters. All but three of Nepal's 157 Peace Corps volunteers have been found safe. There are no Peace Corp workers in India. The U.S. is sending financial aid to both counties. Britain, U.N. agencies and the Red Cross sent medical teams to Nepal.
column9: Massive earthquake devastates large areas of Nepal and India.
column10: The worst earthquake in this region since 1950, registering 6.5 on the Richter scale, hit near the Nepal-India border killing at least 750 and injuring thousands.  Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.
column11: The deadliest earthquake in this region since 1950, hit near the Nepal-India border killing at least 750 people and injuring thousands.  The magnitude 6.5 quake, with its epicenter about 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, Nepal, was felt as far away as New Delhi and Calcutta.  The hardest hit areas were Bihar state in India and the Dharan district of Nepal.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.   Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  In Nepal police bulldozed more than 50 houses considered too unsafe to be habitable.
column12: The deadliest earthquake in this region since 1950 hit near the Nepal-India border.  At least 750 people died and thousands were injured.  The magnitude 6.5 quake, lasting about 40 seconds and with its epicenter about 100 miles southeast of Katmandu, Nepal, was felt as far away as New Delhi, Calcutta and northern Bangladesh.  The hardest hit areas were the Dharan district of Nepal, where 50,000 to 60,000 houses were destroyed and the Bihar state of India.  With cracks in the embankments of six Bihar state rivers, flooding could be the next threat there.  Aftershocks kept people terrified for days.  The army, police, and local inhabitants are taking part in rescue efforts in both countries.  Foreign aid began arriving.  Earthquake damage and monsoon rains have paralyzed rail and road transportation thus hindering rescue efforts and isolating some remote areas.  Nepalese police bulldozed more than 50 houses considered too unsafe to be habitable.  Concerned American parents heard from some of their Peace Corps volunteer children in Nepal where all but three volunteers have been tracked down. And in Bhaktapur, Nepal, political rivals of a former legislator accused him of distributing relief supplies to only his supporters and beat him to death.

column5: Lucille Ball, TV's comic genius, had major impact on the industry
column6: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77 starred along with her husband Desi Arnaz in perhaps the finest television series, "I Love Lucy". Together they founded Desilu Productions, which eventually took over RKO and produced very popular television shows.  Expressions of sympathy poured in from all over the country.
column7: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77, will long be remembered.  She made her craft look easy, spontaneous and unrehearsed.  The result was the durable and probably the finest series in television, "I Love Lucy".  She starred in the show along with her husband Desi Arnaz, and together they founded Desilu Productions, which eventually took over RKO Studios and television and produced many popular television shows.  The couple had two children and divorced in 1960.  Condolences poured in form all over the country in which she was credited with helping to establish television as the nation's leading entertainment industry.
column8: Lucille Ball, who died in April 1989 at the age of 77, will long beremembered.  She made her craft look easy, spontaneous andunrehearsed.  The result was the durable and probably the finestseries in television history, "I Love Lucy".  She starred with herhusband, Desi Arnaz, in the '50s show and together they founded DesiluProductions, which eventually took over RKO Studios.  She was anastute businesswoman as well as a talented entertainer and Desiluproduced some of the most popular programs of the '50s and '60s. Balland Arnaz divorced in 1960.  They had two children.  At her deaththere was an outpouring of sympathy from the very famous to thousandsof her ordinary fans.  She was particularly remembered in her hometownof Jamestown New York where she had contributed to local charities,civic events and Jamestown Community College.  Following the breakupof her first marriage, she married Gary Morton, her husband at herdeath.  Miss Ball had a successful career before television, starringin 75 films.  She died in Los Angeles, following emergency heartsurgery.  William Paley, Chairman of CBS said that she helped toestablish television as the nation's leading entertainment industryand that her legacy would last forever.
column9: Everyone loved Lucille Ball, the queen of television comedy.
column10: When Lucille Ball died at 77, fans from presidents to neighbors to co-stars to critics paid tributes to her life, person and comedic skills.  Although she was a chorus girl, model, movie star, and television entrepreneur, she is best remembered for "I Love Lucy," a 1950's show that revolutionized television comedy.
column11: The Queen of TV comedy and entrepreneur, Lucille Ball, died on April 26, 1989 at 77.  Presidents, comedians and actors, neighbors, residents of her hometown, television critics, surviving co-stars, and just plain fans paid tributes to her.  More than 2,000 attended three memorial services.  She was a chorus girl, model, and in 75 movies, but is best remembered for her physical and verbal comedy and superb timing evident on television.  She and her husband, Desi Arnaz, revolutionized television comedy with "I Love Lucy," which was filmed before a live audience, becoming a rerun gold mine, still seen world-wide.
column12: The Queen of TV comedy, Lucille Ball, died on April 26, 1989, from a ruptured abdominal aorta.  President Bush, former President Reagan, the president of CBS, American comedians and actors, neighbors, residents of her hometown, television critics, and just plain fans paid tributes to her.  Her burial was private, but more than 2,000 attended three memorial services held on May 8.  Bob Hope, a frequent co-star and friend, created a TV special in her honor.  Two of her surviving TV co-stars, Gail Gordon and Keith Thibodeaux, remembered her fondly.  She is best remembered for her physical and verbal comedy and superb timing.  She was born in 1911 in Jamestown, N.Y., and, after staring in high school plays, became a model and chorus girl, moving in 1933 to Hollywood.  There, she was in over 75 movies, usually playing the second banana.  In 1940 she married Desi Arnaz, and together they revolutionized television comedy with "I Love Lucy" which started in 1951.  Filmed with three cameras before a live audience, it became a rerun gold mine and has been seen in 80 countries.  After her divorce, she remarried and continued to be a successful television entrepreneur and star of television and screen.

column3: Hitting Baghdad where it hurts, more countries have joined U.N.-sanctioned boycott oil Iraq and Kuwait. On Tuesday, countries ranging powerful Japan neutral Switzerland tiny Cyprus cut petroleum imports effort convince Baghdad government withdraw its troops that invaded Kuwait Thursday. Turkey announced it was shut twin Iraqi oil pipelines that run it Mediterranean  carrying half Baghdad's crude output  and cutting trade Iraq. Baghdad's only other major pipelines exporting crude run Saudi Arabia, where flow has been drastically reduced. The U.N. Security Council Monday voted impose broad economic sanctions Iraq invading small oil-rich Kuwait. The measure forbids loans Iraq or Kuwait and prohibits any activities, including transfer money, that would help two countries export their goods. Sanctions adopted European Economic Community Saturday froze Iraqi assets and suspended purchase oil two Arab countries. More 90 percent imports Iraq 12-nation EEC are petroleum products. The EEC also suspended arms sales Iraq. Switzerland, which is not member United Nations, made unusual move Tuesday joining U.N. sanctions and banned all trade Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. In addition, Switzerland prohibited all payments and other financial transfers Iraq and Kuwait. Denmark, Norway and Sweden also announced embargoes all trade countries. Japan's participation U.N. sanctions was seen especially key Tokyo has taken low profile Middle East, which supplies much its petroleum needs. Japan imports 99 percent its oil. China joined U.N. decision embargo arms sales Iraq, has been less vocal other major countries condemning invasion. China sold arms Iran and Iraq their eight-year war and is major Iraqi trade partner. Cyprus' sacrifice joining embargo was give 70 percent its oil imports, government spokesman Akis Fantis said. Cyprus has sufficient oil supplies last end August, he said, we are already process taking steps secure alternative sources ... The worldwide closing ranks Iraqi oil imports is likely lead higher petroleum prices, which have already risen dramatically invasion and could have major impact world economy. Wholesale oil prices soared five-year highs New York Monday. France will introduce controls Thursday prices petroleum products prevent refiners using Iraq's invasion Kuwait excuse raise prices, acting Premier Pierre Beregovoy announced Tuesday. An official Petroleum Association Japan said he was unaware any increase price gasoline consumers. The official, who refused be further identified, said it would be least three months sanctions could be expected force higher gas prices Japan. An Iraqi airways jet carrying 78 foreigners and number Iraqi citizens arrived today, first commercial flight allowed out Iraq it invaded Kuwait, Japanese Embassy spokesman said. The mostly Japanese tourists arrived Amman airport 6:15 p.m. (11:15 a.m. EDT) 34 members Iraqi football team, said spokesman condition anonymity. It was not immediately known if there were Americans board. He said that plane was due leave Amman undisclosed destination. The spokesman said plane was supposed land Vienna, it was denied landing rights. The U.N. Security Council Monday voted economic sanctions that ban all trade and military ties Iraq. Jordan's information minister, Ibrahim Izzedine, said earlier today that U.S. government had asked Jordan facilitate entrance Iraq American diplomats and their dependents. Izzedine said request was made U.S. Embassy Amman. Thousands Westerners have been stranded Kuwait and Iraq Iraq invaded Kuwait Thursday. They include more 350 who were British Airways flight that was caught unrest Kuwait. A British Airways spokeswoman said today substantial number those passengers arrived safely Baghdad Monday. Among passengers were 28 Americans, who also turned Baghdad hotel and appear be fine, U.S. official said Washington. In addition, Kuwaiti businessman said 1,000 people day were fleeing Kuwait desert Saudi Arabia. The businessman, who arrived London British Airways flight Bahrain today, said Kuwaitis and expatriates, including Westerners, were joining convoys escape Iraqi forces. Jordan's borders Iraq had been closed Iraqi side Thursday morning, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. The provisional government free Kuwait set Iraq had threatened Sunday hold hostage citizens countries imposing sanctions it. A U.S. diplomat said Washington had instructed American citizens living or visiting Iraq and Kuwait leave when circumstances permit. Here are some quotes Iraq's invasion Kuwait: Here is brief chronology dispute Iraq and Kuwait oil production and their common border. July 17  Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accuses Kuwait and United Arab Emirates flooding oil market and driving prices down, and that move cost Iraq $14 billion lost oil revenue. He further charges that Arab states Persian Gulf are conspiring United States and Israel weaken Iraq's economy and undermine its military buildup. July 18  Iraq accuses Kuwait stealing $2.4 billion worth oil wells disputed border Iraq and seeking wreck Iraq's economy overproducing oil and thus pushing prices. July 20  Kuwaiti officials suggest Iraq's sudden outburst belligerence is aimed getting its creditors  including Kuwait  write billions dollars debts 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. July 24  The U.S. Defense Department announces that U.S. Navy warships and aircraft are holding short-notice exercise Persian Gulf United Arab Emirates, 600 miles southeast Kuwait-Iraqi border. Kuwait reinstates state alert it declared July 16 and canceled three days tension two oil-producing countries. July 25  The Iraqi government Baghdad says that it will not be intimidated U.S. pressure its oil dispute neighboring Kuwait, and Saddams summons U.S. ambassador talks. President Hosni Mubarak Egypt says Iraq and Kuwait plan meet Saudi Arabia effort resolve their dispute. July 26  OPEC ministers Geneva agree halt overproduction hopes pushing price crude oil. Kuwait and United Arab Emirates pledge abide agreement. Analysts say Saddam clearly influenced outcome meetings. July 31  Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegations meet Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, negotiate oil and border dispute. Diplomats say Iraq has massed 100,000 troops Kuwait's border, more triple number originally estimated. That number dwarfs Kuwaiti army, which has total 20,000 troops. Aug. 1  Iraq pulls out talks 2-week-old border, oil and money dispute Kuwait shortly it sends its forces invade oil-rich sheikdom. Aug. 2  Iraq's powerful army overruns Kuwait dawn tank-led troops quickly seized ruler's palace and other government buildings. THE INVASION: Iraq's troops, led 350 tanks, crossed border dawn Thursday, and seized Kuwaiti palace and government buildings 40 miles away. Early Friday, invaders controlled Kuwait city, capital. The soldiers were also making sweeps southern oilfields, according residents and Lloyds' insurance service London. Diplomatic sources estimate more 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded, mainly Emiri Guard which bore main brunt invasion. Kuwait's Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah fled safety Saudi Arabia.  THE FORCES: Iraq, country more 17 million, has Arab world's most battle-trained army, and had massed more 100,000 soldiers Kuwaiti border. Kuwait, oil-rich city-state, has 1.9 million residents  60 percent foreigners  and army 20,300 soldiers.  CAUSE OF CONFLICT: President Saddam Hussein Iraq accused Kuwait stealing oil its territory and forcing oil prices overproduction. Kuwait and U.N. diplomats dismissed Iraq's claim that it invaded request Kuwaiti revolutionaries.  REACTION: The U.N. Security Council voted 14-0 condemn invasion. President Bush denounced it naked agression. He froze Iraq's assets United States and blocked almost all Iraqi imports, including oil. The order also froze Kuwait property U.S. jurisdiction  move intended keep Iraq seizing it. The Soviets also condemned invasion and stopped arms sales Iraq. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador said nation had asked American military intervention. A Pentagon source said U.S. naval group was diverted Persian Gulf. Oil prices soared frenzied trading fears invasion would reduce supply oil. Iranian editorial writers are rejoicing now that world is waking one their most hated bogeymen: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. A Monday headline: We warned you Frankenstein would torment his creators. Saddam attacked Iran September 1980 series border skirmishes, spawning war that dragged August 1988 cease-fire. The conflict has still not formally ended. Iran's late fundamentalist patriarch, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, vowed years unseat Saddam. Never loss vivid phrase, he compared accepting cease-fire Saddam drinking poison. The status Great Satan was reserved United States, all-encompassing public enemy No. 1 Islamic Republic. Iran frequently accuses U.S. and Saddam trying undermine Islamic revolution. Saddam conveniently boasts having alone staunched tide radical Islam. In fact one his reasons invading Kuwait Thursday, Iraqi press noted, was its gall demanding back tens billions dollars loaned Iraq war Saddam says he fought all Arabs. Over six months, successful U.N.-sponsored efforts face-to-face negotiations Iraq and Iran robbed Iranian newspapers and television commentators favorite target. Saddam's overthrow emir Kuwait changed all that. Old scores came brimming surface. Kuwait, all, reflagged tankers United States Iran-Iraq war, ushering reason arrival U.S. Navy Persian Gulf force. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency printed excerpts Mondya editorial Ettela'at newspaper that was headlined: Foster child turns rapaciously nourisher Kuwait. It noted that Kuwait had blindly supported Iraq, little knowing that it was feeding wild beast her neighborhood. Saddam has also been called generalissimo and The Invader. Under Frankenstein headline, IRNA said its commentary: For time being, tiny Kuwait ... breathes no more. With its sheikh stateless person, and its powerful dinar which bankrolled Iraqi military mere garbage, Kuwait is nonentity, swallowed dangerous pet it reared. Despite all attention dangerous pet, Great Satan has not been forgotton. According Iran's pundits, Great Satan planned it all. It wanted get Navy back Persian Gulf.
column5: Iraq invaded Kuwait August 1990. US sent navy, world imposed sanctions.
column6: On August 2nd, 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait with 100,000 troops, destroying government  installations and killing 200. Saddam Hussain, claiming invitation by revolutionaries, accused Kuwait of driving down oil prices and stealing Iraqi oil. The US sent naval forces to the Persian Gulf. The US, UN, and EEC imposed economic and military sanctions. Oil prices soared.
column7: On August 2nd, 1990, Iraq occupied Kuwait with 100,000 troops, destroying government buildings and installations, killing 200, and replacing fleeing Kuwaitis with Iraqis. Saddam Hussain accused Kuwait of overproducing to drive down oil prices and stealing oil from Iraqi border wells. Iraq claimed it invaded at revolutionaries' request. Kuwait said Iraq invaded because Kuwait pressed for war loan repayment. Kuwait appealed for US and UN help. Bush pledged to defend its Persian Gulf interests and sent a naval group. The US, UN, and EEC imposed widely-supported trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq threatened to hold citizens of sanction-imposing countries hostage. Oil prices soared.
column8: On August 2nd, 1990, 100,000 Iraqi troops massing on Kuwait's border crossed over, occupying the country and destroying all government buildings and installations except for the water system and oil equipment. Over 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded. Iraq facilitated residents' departures then trucked in Iraqis to replace Kuwaitis and change the population's make-up. Thousands fled to Saudi Arabia, including the leadership. Jordan also took in refugees.Saddam Hussain accused Kuwait of exceeding OPEC production quotas to drive down prices, and stealing oil from Iraqi border wells. Iraq claimed it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries who staged a coup, which Kuwait denied. Kuwait said Iraq invaded because it demanded Iraq pay back billions loaned during the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq War. Iran rejoiced that the world was waking up to Saddam Hussein.  Kuwait appealed for US and UN help. Bush said the US would take any action necessary to defend its Persian Gulf interests and diverted a naval group to the Gulf. The US, UN, and EEC imposed trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait, supported widely by other countries. The Soviets and China stopped Iraqi arms sales. Iraq rounded up Westerners in Kuwait and threatened to hold hostage citizens of countries imposing sanctions. Oil prices hit five-year highs.
column9: Iraq invades and occupies Kuwait, bringing worldwide anger and sanctions.
column10: With little warning, Iraq invaded tiny Kuwait on August 2, quickly taking the country.  Many fled as Iraq began rounding up foreign nationals, flying some to Jordan.  Reactions to the invasion have been strong.  The United Nations' trade and military sanctions are being honored.  Oil prices are soaring.
column11: After two weeks of accusations and maneuvering, Iraq invaded tiny Kuwait on August 2 with 100,000 battle-trained troops, quickly taking the country.  While the Kuwaiti emir and refugees fled to Saudi Arabia, Iraq began rounding up foreign nationals and repopulating the nation with Iraqi citizens.  Some foreigners were taken to Iraq, while some were flown to Jordan.  Reactions to the invasion have been strong. The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed trade and military sanctions and President Bush said he would defend U.S. interests.  Iran rejoiced.  Most nations are strongly enforcing these sanctions as oil prices soar and Iraq begins defensive preparations.
column12: The Iraqi occupation of Kuwait began on August 2 when masses of combat-experienced troops poured across the border, quickly taking the country.  The Kuwait emir fled to Saudi Arabia.  The dispute began in mid-July when Iraq, a nation with 17 million, accused tiny Kuwait of stealing oil and flooding the market.  As Iraqi troops mobilized, efforts to avoid a confrontation failed.  While Iraqi said it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries, a Kuwaiti spokesman called this a false pretext.  President Bush said he would defend U.S. interests in the Persian Gulf.  Iran, which fought an 8-year war with Iraq, rejoiced that the world saw the "Frankenstein" created by the United States and Kuwait.  The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed trade and military sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait.  Most nations strongly enforced these sanctions, as oil prices soared.Iraq rounded-up foreign nationals in Kuwait, including passengers of a British airliner, and took many to Iraq.  An Iraqi jet finally brought some to Jordan on August 7.  Refugees poured into Saudi Arabia.  Some reported that Iraqis were moving in and being given Kuwaiti identities.  Iraq began evacuation drills and warned of U.S. or Israeli actions.

column3: Iran is deliberately underreporting number casualties Thursday's massive earthquake out fear political backlash, leaders group seeking overthrow country's Islamic leadership say. The regime is very much fearful public outrage, said Shahin Gobadi, spokesman People's Mojahedin Iran. They're very much afraid political aftershocks. As Gobadi spoke Friday, members organization denounced Iran's government noisy rally held park street White House. Northern Iran was stuck Thursday earthquake measuring 7.3 and 7.7 Richter Scale. Iran has told United Nations that death toll is least 36,000, Gobadi said his organization has received estimates closer 100,000. Gobadi said country cannot properly assist earthquake victims because its treasury has been spent war neighboring Iraq and internal opposition. They have been very late assisting people, he said. Sympathy earthquake victims was secondary issue chanting, flag-waving rally participants, who also carried signs criticizing their native country. Planning event began three weeks earthquake, part Friday's activities focused Iran's stricken residents. Gobadi said shoddy housing which government forced people live was cause widespread loss life. This regime has brought them nothing devastation and misery. This regime has devoted all its resources senseless war Iraq and oppression people home, he said. A U.N.-sponsored cease-fire was declared last year eight years Iran-Iraq war. Iran's Islamic republic was established 1979 Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi was deposed Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and militants seized U.S. Embassy Tehran, taking 66 Americans hostage. The United States broke diplomatic relations Iran April 1980. The shah died exile July 1980, U.S. hostages were freed six months later and Khomeini died last June. Gobadi said his 25-year-old group had helped depose shah had no part organizing Islamic republic. Even this tragedy which we grieve we cannot trust regime Iran, Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., told estimated 3,000 people attending rally. There were many, many victims this tragedy and there are victims now whose needs need be addressed people United States, he said. Dymally, member House Foreign Affairs Committee, praised President Bush's offer humanitarian aid Iran said Bush must make sure assistance is channeled non-government groups. The State Department said Friday that Iran was willing accept earthquake relief American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian organizations. An anti-American newspaper Iran said Sunday United States is partly blame death tens thousands people last week's earthquake. The criminal role America Iran's became evident once again recent earthquake, Jomhuri Islami said editorial reported official Islamic Republic News Agency. Our people, rubble, chant `Death America' and pray God cut hands United States ... those hands stretched out help, it said. It argued that plundering Iran's oil and other resources 25 years, United States had prevented use small part national wealth urban development projects and advanced (anti-seismic) building construction systems. Even its expulsion Iran, U.S. government imposing economic sanctions and launching several other plots, halted renovation country, editorial added. The newspaper was implying that these actions United States had blocked diversion funds earthquake safety measures. If United States has real humanitarian objectives and intended help Iranian nation, it should do only one thing, stop hatching plots, newspaper said. It called Iranians reject relief offers United States and other governments whose hands are stained blood Iranian people. Iran, odds United States 1979 seizure hostages U.S. Embassy Tehran, has said it would welcome relief American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups. The two nations have no diplomatic ties. Countries worldwide, friendly and hostile Tehran's Islamic government, sent supplies, medical personnel and condolences Iran, where 40,000 people have died earthquake. Iran's deadliest earthquake 1976 jolted northern part country Thursday, devastating towns and injuring least 100,000 people. The United States sent message condolence and expressed its willingness provide humanitarian aid. Iran, which has had no diplomatic ties United States 1979 seizure hostages U.S. Embassy Tehran, said it would welcome relief American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups. Moderate Arab countries which Iran has had prickly relations  Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan  also offered their support. An official statement distributed late Friday Saudi Press Agency said kingdom followed deep sorrow news tragedy. The kingdom Saudi Arabia ... declares its readiness help extending assistance those harmed tragedy, wishing help ease pain afflicted sons Iranian Moslem nation, it said. Jordan announced Saturday it was sending medical aid Iran, details were not immediately clear. King Hussein sent condolences Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani Friday what is believed be first direct contact Jordanian and Iranian heads state almost decade. Jordan backed Iraq eight-year Iran-Iraq war, which ended cease-fire August 1988, and one point sent hundreds Jordanian volunteers fight alongside Iraqi soldiers. Egypt was sending two military planes supplies, Middle East News Agency reported. President Hosni Mubarak offered aid framework Egypt's concern provide help brothers and friends, especially times natural disasters. The official Soviet news agency Tass reported that professional lifesaving team Armenian capital Yerevan flew Saturday Iran. The team gained experience devastating 1988 earthquake Armenia that killed 25,000 people. Thousands residents predominantly Moslem Soviet republic Azerbaijan, which borders Iran, donated tons flour, rice and tea, and contributed more $500,000 special earthquake fund, Tass said. The Italian Red Cross sent plane Iran Saturday relief supplies, including tents, blankets and medicine. In Paris, French government, which already has sent 200-member civil defense team  including rescuers, medical personnel and search dogs  said Saturday it would send entire mobile hospital unit if Iran wanted it. In West Germany, Foreign Ministry said that it was sending tents, blankets, hospital equipment and cooking equipment Iran. Eight tons was being shipped Saturday and government has chartered jumbo jet transport 100 tons equipment Monday. At Vatican, Pope John Paul II sent aid earthquake victims and message condolence Iranian leaders. The Vatican said statement that donation unspecified amount was provide most immediate needs population hurt this huge earthquake. John Paul also sent telegram papal nuncio, or diplomatic representative, Tehran saying pope is praying fervently wounded and families victims. The Indian government said it would donate medicine, blankets and other relief supplies worth more $500,000. China's Red Cross said it was sending $106,000 worth relief supplies, state-run television said Saturday. The Polish government was sending 5 tons powdered milk, ton bed sheets, ton medicine and 3 tons blankets and clothing, according Polish media reports. Malaysia was providing more $90,000 relief aid. Foreign Ministry Secretary-General Ahmad Kamil Jaafar told reporters Saturday money would be used buy medicine, food, powdered milk, tents and other essential items. The earthquake that struck northern Iran brought reminders another quake that devastated Soviet Armenia 1988. Like Thursday's earthquake Iran, Dec. 7, 1988, earthquake Armenia killed 25,000 people. Most died structures that collapsed when quake hit. It's very similar what we had Armenia, said Russ Needham, geophysicist U.S. Geological Survey. The Armenian quake was measured 6.9 Richter scale, Thursday's earthquake shook earth magnitude 7.7 according U.S. Geological Survey. In Iranian quake, casualty count was pushed fact that people were indoors and asleep time, just midnight. Many victims lived fragile homes built ceramic-type brick or adobe that collapses easily. In Armenian quake, Soviet parliamentary report later blamed high number fatalities shoddily built buildings. Most casualties earthquakes are caused something falling top you, said Needham telephone interview Golden, Colo. The quake struck area Iran where most buildings are built flood plain loosely deposited soil that shifts earthquake and allows structures collapse, Needham said. The 7.7-magnitude quake was largest ever recorded that area, where two major plates earth's crust meet, he said. Iran is very active seismic region, he said, and that there have been many smaller quakes. Twelve earthquakes greater magnitude 7 have occurred Iran last 30 years, Needham said. A quake magnitude 7 is considered major earthquake, capable widespread, heavy damage populated areas. Most casualties earthquakes are caused something falling top you, said Russ Needham, geophysist U.S. Geological Survey that monitors ground motion world. The quake hit 12:30 a.m. Iran, when most people were their homes, Needham said Thursday telephone interview Golden, Colo.
