column5: Responses to the Northern California Earthquake of October 17, 1989
column6: California struggled to recover from the earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989. The Governor called a special session of the legislature to deal with the disaster and despite heavy losses, the insurance industry appeared optimistic. In Washington the White House launched into furious activity to answer critics of its performance in earlier crises.
column7: The California earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989 caused extensive damage. Despite heavy insurance losses, insurance company stocks posted gains as investors bet on increases in insurance rates producing a long-term increase in profits. In Washington, the White House appeared hyperactive, anxious to show its responsiveness to the disaster. In Sacramento, Governor Deukmejian called a special session of the legislature to deal with the crisis. Critics accused him of blaming others for the collapse of freeways and called on him to get on with reconstruction and a temporary increase of the gasoline tax so hundreds of thousands of commuters could get to work.
column8: The northern California earthquake of October 17, 1989 caused extensive damage to buildings and roadways. An official of the California Seismic Safety Commission said that assessing the disaster was "like the blind man trying to feel an elephant." Another on-site observer commented that the quake "was like somebody slugging a punching bag. Usually earthquakes pass, but this one went on and on...It was very very bad." Estimates of the loss to insurers ranged from $2 billion to $4 billion. Ironically, despite the record losses to insurers, insurance company stocks posted strong gains as investors bet that market forces and action by state regulators would result in higher insurance rates and long-term profits. In Washington the Bush White House flew into a whirlwind of activity to show the administration's ability for rapid response. In Sacramento Governor Deukmejian called a special session of the California legislature to deal with the disaster, but was perceived as blaming others for the collapse of freeways. Critics called on him to stop pointing fingers and get on with reconstruction. The Governor had earlier opposed an increase in the gasoline tax intended to augment transportation funding -- a step which appeared highly desirable after the quake left hundreds of thousands of commuters unable to reach work.
column9: Insurers will not suffer financial damage due to California earthquake.
column10: The White House and the California government are provided aid to Tuesday's California earthquake victims. Only 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area are insured. Insurers may have to pay billions but no company is expected to suffer financial damage. Insurers price-cutting may end as prices rise from reinsurance investments.
column11: In the aftermath of California's earthquake Tuesday, the White House reacted quickly to get federal aid flowing. The governor of California assured victims the state also would provide aid. Only about 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area are said to be insured.Insurers may have to pay billions of dollars for the earthquake but no company is expected to suffer serious financial damage. Insurers as a whole are likely to increase the amount of reinsurance they buy which, in turn, will translate into an overall price rise, thus ending the price-cutting war between them the past two years.
column12: In the aftermath of California's earthquake Tuesday, the White House reacted quickly--partly to get federal aid flowing--and also to protect an image of the White House in action. The White House and the Federal Emergency Management Agency were accused of slow response to the Exxon Valdez oil spill and Hurricane Hugo. The Governor of California is assuring victims that the state will provide aid.  Analysts and industry spokesmen say only about 25-30% of homes in the San Francisco area have earthquake insurance.Insurers may have to pay billions of dollars for the earthquake.  The damage goes far beyond that of Hurricane Hugo last month.  Insurers are rushing into the area to process claims but no company is expected to suffer serious financial damage. Investors hope the financial and psychological impact of the earthquake will stem price-cutting wars between insurers the past two years. It is predicted that the quake damages may in fact lead to rate hikes. Insurers and state legislators are battling over rates and how they are set. Insurers as a whole are likely to increase the amount of reinsurance they buy, which will translate into an overall price rise.

column3: SAM WALTON was arguably most important retailer his generation. Theson Oklahoma real-estate broker, he opened first general store inwhat was become Wal-Mart chain Bentonville, backwaters ofArkansas, 1950, writes Martin Dickson.By 1991 chain's sales had risen nearly Dollars 44bn, making it theworld's largest retailer terms revenues, and Walton familyprobably America's richest.Wal-Mart now operates 43 US states, selling goods ranging detergentsto golf clubs.The chain's success stemmed Mr Walton's personality andwillingness challenge accepted retailing orthodoxy.He was frugal, modest man who worked extremely long hours spartanroom his Bentonville headquarters delighted getting out theoffice tour stores and meet customers and staff, whom he insisted oncalling 'associates.'He would deliver pep-talks employees extolling virtues thrift andcustomer satisfaction, long these became fashionable managementbuzz-words.Employee satisfaction - idea which is only now gaining wider acceptancein US service industries - was also vital ingredient Waltonphilosophy.He buoyed staff morale cheer-leading sessions, bonus payments goodperformance and profit-sharing plans which allowed some employees verymodest means retire relatively wealthy.Eight years ago, when Wal-Mart's profits were better expected, he kepta promise staff dressing grass-skirt dance hula WallStreet.Also essential Wal-Mart's growth was its pioneering high volume,cut-price retailing throughout year, rather periodic saleswhich rivals relied generate customer loyalty.'Low prices always' became Wal-Mart's motto.Mr Walton also disproved conventional wisdom that large discount storescould not operate successfully small, rural towns US south.It was precisely such locations which became bedrock business,though process Wal-Mart put out business hundreds small mainstreet stores, prompting bitter resistance some towns which Mr Waltontended blunt generous charitable donations.Forty years Sam Walton first hungout his shingle, Walton's 5&10 will reopen show how littlerural storekeeper built discount retail empire.Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s Visitors Center opens Wednesday thesame building downtown square where Walton first opened forbusiness May 9, 1950.The center chronicles rise nation's fastest-growingdiscount chain, using displays and audio-video presentations. Bill Clinton, thededication speaker.Aside other displays and presentations, center alsohas replica Sam Walton's original office store,including many fixtures he used 40 years ago.Also display is photograph young Sam Walton, fat-facedbaby born Oklahoma 1920s. He lost lease that one,and relocated Bentonville. In onevideo, David Glass, who succeeded Sam Walton chief executive ofWal-Mart 1988, recalled his impressions attending theopening second Wal-Mart Discount City Harrison 1964.The first store, Rogers, opened two years earlier.I thought myself this is absolutely worst discountstore, or retail store, I have ever seen, said Glass, who waspresident drugstore chain time.And Wal-Mart Vice Chairman Donald Soderquist recalls that whenWalton took his idea putting discount stores rural areas toBen Franklin headquarters Chicago, officials there just reallydidn't see future it.Don Shinkle, Wal-Mart's director corporate and publicaffairs, attributed Wal-Mart's success its associates  theterm employees first coined 1972 stress that all Wal-Martemployees are partners company  and Sam Walton'sleadership and knack hiring right person righttime.At start 1990, Wal-Mart owned 1,402 stores, employed272,000 and listed sales $25.8 billion. Sam's Wholesale Clubclosed out year 123 units and Wal-Mart announced plans toenter California market.MADE IN AMERICA: MY STORYBy Sam WaltonDoubleday, Dollars 22.50. 269 pagesBeing American folk hero is tricky assignment, Ross Perot found out.The problem is that great American public likes its boot-strapentrepreneurs be very rich and very upright. In country where businesspractices are not overly genteel, this is tough combination achieve. Avast media circus, meanwhile, is quick expose any flaws.Sam Walton, founder Wal-Mart chain discount supermarkets who diedof cancer April, negotiated these pitfalls much better most. When,in 1985, Forbes magazine declared him America's richest entrepreneur, thepaparazzi descended obscure corner Arkansas, mainly occupied bychicken farmers, where Walton made his home. What they found was happilymarried, much-liked billionaire who enjoyed quail hunting, breakfasted atthe local Holiday Inn, and drove battered pick-up truck, twohub-caps. Folksy was understatement.Since then, some aspects Wal-Mart's business - its anti-union policies,the impact its Dollars 40bn annual sales hundreds Mom-and-Pop shops -have been subject critical scrutiny. So, extent, have lesswholesome adventures four Walton children. But no one has ever beenable make Sam himself look bad. The worst that has been said is that hewas rather dull.Walton is not dash anyone's illusions. Readers will either find hisautobiography lashed 'good ol common-sense and lot harmless, ifcharming, anecdotes. Or they will find it dreary and downbeat. Walton makesno excuses: 'I realise this may sound boring most you,' he writes onestage, 'but one my best items ever was mattress pad called Bedmate .. . .'A few snippets are more revealing character. There cannot be manybillionaires who admit that they 'never learned handwriting too well' - andhave guts include photograph which demonstrates point.Meanwhile, competitive energy which Sam Walton applied his businessis inescapable. In one many contributions friends and family, DonSoderquist, Wal-Mart's chief operating officer, tells finding Sam oneSaturday morning his hand and knees local Kmart store, analysinghis rival's stock. And his wife, casual aside, notes that when thecouple was holiday Italy their luggage vanished while her husband wasoff similar scouting mission.But it is David Glass, Wal-Mart's current chief executive, who perhapscaptures entrepreneurial Walton spirit best. Explaining annualcontest which Wal-Mart executives choose one 'volume producing item' topromote, he recalls time Sam (who won) selected minnow bucketsfor carrying bait. Glass was more happily teamed apple juice. 'So Iwould go stores, and get them take that minnow bucket . . .put ice it, ice juice and give away samples out his minnowbucket. I particularly it stores I knew (Sam) was going visit. Itdrove him crazy, and he got that minnow bucket pretty quick . . . .'But reader can't help feeling that cosy yarns tell only half thetruth. Sam Walton was salesman core, and seems have packagedhimself all skill that he once applied selling gooey southernsweet called Moon Pies.For most part, this makes engaging, if one-dimensional, portrait.Occasionally, it just grates. 'I had bought bank Bentonville, aboutabout Dollars 300,000,' Walton remarks, example, 'just little old bankwith only Dollars 3.5m deposits. But it helped me learn lot aboutfinancing things.' Rule No.2 says just case thecustomer's wrong, revert rule No.1.If principles sound old-fashioned and homespun, they arebecause that's way Sam is, people who know him say.He shuns limelight that his company's success has shed himand has decided refuse almost all press requests interviews.He's happy chat folks his stores, though.He also regularly reminds Wal-Mart associates thathospitality customers is crucial. He preaches it person or viahigh-tech satellite hookup his stores.Wal-Mart employees became known associates companyeffort prove it cared employees, partly thwart unionorganizing effort late 1960s.One most sensitive subjects Walton is fortune he'samassed.A close associate says Sam would probably give anything notto be named Fortune magazine's list country's wealthiestpeople. The magazine has estimated that his immediate family's stakein Wal-Mart stock is worth $6.8 billion.Sam Walton is more interested his backhand he is hisbank account, says Don Shinkle, Wal-Mart spokesman.Samuel Moore Walton turns 71 March 29. He was born inKingfisher, Okla., and grew son farm-mortgage banker.He graduated University Missouri economicsdegree 1940 and joined J.C. Penney Co. management trainee inDes Moines, Iowa. After serving three years Army, he went toArkansas and opened Ben Franklin five-and-dime store, eventuallybecoming company's biggest franchisee.The seeds Wal-Mart empire were sown when Sam and hisbrother James L., or Bud, opened first Wal-Mart Discount City in1962. The rest will probably earn entry history U.S.retail trade.Bud is senior vice president and board member Wal-Mart.Three four grown children Sam and his wife Helen had areinvolved company various capacities.Sam hasn't slowed much, enjoying hunting and tennis much asever, and is said not suffer effects bout withleukemia, now remission. He spends less time office sincehanding most responsiblities David Glass. Sam is stillchairman board.Glass doesn't hesitate when asked if Wal-Mart can flourishwithout Sam. The answer is emphatic yes because, he says, Wehave great people. The Walton family will always be involved, headds.Commenting future, Glass says: We'll be judged whatwe produce today. Tomorrow, what we've done won'tmatter.Wal-Mart founder Sam Waltonpitched help check-out clerks his store this FloridaPanhandle city when electronic glitch shut cashregisters.The 71-year-old Walton, considered be one world'srichest people, grabbed note pad Tuesday evening and startedhand-writing merchandise prices customers so their bills couldbe tallied calculators quickly.People began recognizing him and coming and greeting him,said store manager Paul Sively. He shook their hands and talked toeveryone he could. The registers were out 45 minutes, andI don't think we had one customer complain.Walton, known his down-home style, made surprise visit tothe store that later Tuesday staged concert country singer JanaJea its parking lot. Walton attends promotional events forhis Arkansas-based chain, and Sively said he had suspected bossmight make appearance.Walton continued talking customers concert. Healso joined singer stage sing duet and led customers inthe Wal-Mart cheer.He was there saying, `Give me W, give me A,' and thecustomers went right him, Sively said. He gotdown do cheerleader's squiggle.'WAL-MART: A HISTORY OF SAM WALTON'S RETAIL PHENOMENON' Sandra S. Vanceand Roy V. Scott Twayne Publishers, New York, Dollars 14.95 240 pagesMany people might be said be personification American Dream;few are better qualified that title Sam Walton.Walton is character it would be difficult invent, all-American boywho became one world's most successful businessmen. The church-goingson farmer born 1918 Kingfisher, Oklahoma, he founded storechain which made him America's richest man, and which, shortly hisdeath 1992, became world's biggest retailer.His company, Wal-Mart, made sales Dollars 55bn last year, and afterWalton's death Fortune magazine reported that his wife and four childrenheld them second-largest fortune world - Dollars 23.5bn.What is most startling Wal-Mart is speed its growth. AlthoughWalton built small chain Ben Franklin variety store franchises from1945, it was not 1962 that he opened his first Wal-Mart discountstore.At time its incorporation 1971, Wal-Mart had only 38 outlets withsales Dollars 44m - not enough earn place trade journal DiscountMerchandiser's list 71 biggest US discount retailers. Ten yearslater, 330 stores and Dollars 1.6bn sales, it was only 33rd-biggestretailer US. Its turnover was only 9 cent that SearsRoebuck, biggest, and 11 cent K mart, second-biggest. Withinanother 10 years, Wal-Mart had overtaken them both.Apart Walton's autobiography completed shortly his death,however, published material company is curiously scarce. This bookattempts fill gap, provide 'scholarly account' rise ofWal-Mart, setting it wider context US retailing, and explaininghow it was achieved.One strength authors identify is Wal-Mart's ability copy and adaptfrom other retailers.Sam Walton not invent discount retailing. Rather, he realised threatdiscounting posed his variety store business and studied depthmany US's leading discounters early 1960s, including Ann andHope, E J Korvette, Spartan's, Fed-Mart, and K mart.Walton learned them all, was unique taking his discount storesinto small towns few thousand people, where shoppers used travellinglong distances were delighted have cut-price store nearby sellingeverything they needed.Another strength is Wal-Mart's openness technology. As early the1950s, Walton realised he was wasting too much time travelling and bought asmall aircraft pilot stores himself - something he continued todo end his life.Sometimes, Walton was more reluctant invest technology, and had bepersuaded colleagues introduce computers, and scanning check-outs -long most retailers had recognised their importance - and investDollars 20m internal satellite communications system. This technologyhelped Wal-Mart build one most efficient distribution systems anyretailer. But perhaps most fundamental reason its success, booksuggests, has been Wal-Mart's streamlined and highly responsive managementstructure.Regional vice-presidents based group headquarters Bentonville,Arkansas, rather costly regional offices, are despatched everyMonday aircraft their regions, spend week visiting stores, workingwith staff and managers, and return day-long merchandising meetingevery Friday.They discuss results, problems and suggestions week 7.30ammeeting Saturdays and immediately afterwards call district managers torelate results. District managers hold conference call theirstore managers, and day is out, contents meeting havebeen communicated all store department heads.The system means employees can make suggestions vice-presidents one weekand, if idea is accepted Saturday meeting, see its implementationbegin week.Even world's most successful retailer makes mistakes, however. One wasWalton's decision stand chairman and chief executive's rolein 1974 favour Ronald Mayer, only return roles 1976after finding he was incapable letting go reins. Another wasWal-Mart's short-lived Hypermart format, which proved too big forgigantist America.Then there was Walton's rash promise do 'hula dance' Wall Street ifWal-Mart achieved 8 cent pre-tax profit margin 1984. It did, andhe did.The book also covers well debate whether Wal-Mart's impact theeconomies small US towns was positive or negative.If there are criticisms, these are that this 'scholarly account' never quitecaptures sheer excitement working world's fastest-growingretailer. Moreover, it makes little attempt predict whether Wal-Mart cancontinue its growth, and conquer rest world way itconquered US.But this is well-researched and accessible account one man's success inbuilding his American dream.He's ranked richest man thenation leading business magazine, folks Bentonville,a town 8,700 people, Sam Walton is just another neighbor.He's just part community, said Curt Loyd, executivedirector Bentonville Chamber Commerce. He's neatperson. He calls Bentonville home, and that is special us.Walton, who prefers bird-hunting, tennis and opening new Wal-Martstores trumpeting his personal financial holdings, is againshunning publicity his third consecutive ranking theworld's top billionaires. According Forbes magazine's July 24edition, Walton family's estimated worth is $8.7 billion, upfrom its 1988 estimate $6.5 billion.He is unavailable, said Wal-Mart spokesman Don Shinkle thesilver-haired founder nation's third-largest retail chain,based Bentonville, 150 miles northwest Little Rock.Shinkle said he received 10 calls reporters Mondaymorning, when Forbes list appeared newspapers. Shinkle saidnews coverage Walton sets press frenzy forcomments him. But 71-year-old businessman declined tocomment.He feels any attention Sam Walton is individual andhe prefers attention Sam Walton (the founder of) company,Shinkle said.He very seldom schedules interviews his feelings. It justputs him position he doesn't want be.But Walton occasionally offers peeks that reveal personalmodesty. Just 1987 stock market crash, which Walton'sfamily-owned chunk Wal-Mart stock lost millions value, hequipped response questions news conference anothertopic that it was only paper. Walton then changed subject.Walton was first listed Forbes nation's richest man inOctober 1985. Three years ago, Forbes also began listing world'swealthiest people. Walton made that listing richest Americanevery year since. This year he ranks third, two Japanesebusinessmen.Shinkle said Walton stays busy visiting many more than1,400 stores operated company he started singlefive-and-dime Rogers more two decades ago. He is out theoffice four days week, spokesman said.He spends most his time talking associates andcustomers, Shinkle said, and he always comes back manyideas them.Wal-Mart calls its sales help associates instead employees.When Walton first made Forbes list richest Americans,recalled Little Rock investment banker Warren Simpson, calls came infrom all billionaire Ozarks.They wanted know stock and company, saidSimpson, who works Stephens Inc. You'd think that he'd beliving New York or LA, not Bentonville, Arkansas. But now peoplejust accept it.When it comes out now, it's just, `Yeah, he's still there,'Simpson said.
column5: Sam Walton, Wal-Mart's multi-billionaire "good 'ole boy", revolutionized American retailing.
column6: Sam Walton revolutionized discount retailing, at the same time becoming the richest man in America.  He took discount shopping to rural America with Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer.  His down-home personality, chronicled in his autobiography and the Wal-Mart visitor's center, permeated the chain's operations.  Scholars also credit his adaptability and responsive management.
column7: Sam Walton, who died in April 1992, revolutionized discount retailing.  Born in Oklahoma, he became the richest man in America. He took discount shopping to rural America founding Wal-Mart Discount City, which became Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer by 1992.  Sam was frugal and homespun and used pop-in visits to test for happy customers and employees.  To preserve his personal legacy, he opened a Wal-Mart visitors' center and wrote his autobiography, filling it with "good ole" anecdotes.  A 1994 book highlighted his ability to copy and adapt, the chain's responsive management, and the chain's impact on Mom-and-Pop stores and anti-union position.
column8: Wal-Mart founder, Sam Walton, who died in April 1992, revolutionizeddiscount retailing.  Born in Oklahoma, the son of a mortgage banker,he became the richest man in America and the second richest in theworld.  After a tour in the army and working in and owning retailingoutlets, he founded Wal-Mart Discount City in 1962.  He took discountshopping to rural America and by 1992 Wal-Mart was the world's largestretailer.  Success can be attributed to Sam's personality.  He wasfrugal, hardworking, old- fashioned, and homespun.  He declared thecustomer always right and continually nurtured employee satisfactionwith bonus payments, profit-sharing plans, and a responsive,streamlined, management system.  He was known for pop-in visits,talking with customers, and personally helping out in an emergency.Sam Walton also worked to preserve his personal legacy.  In 1990 theWal-Mart Stores Inc., Visitors Center opened to chronicle the rise ofthe chain.  He also wrote his autobiography, filling it with anecdotesabout his "good ole" common sense.  A scholarly book was released in1994, which highlighted his ability to copy and adapt and addressedsome of the negative aspects of the giant chain, including itsanti-union stand and its impact on small town Mom-and-Popstores.
column9: Sam Walton dies. Master discounter founded and directed Wal-Mart.
column10: Sam Walton's chain was the country's largest retailer. He was the country's richest man. Wal-Mart grossed 44 billion dollars in the year before he died. Despite his wealth, he lived humbly.He was criticized for anti-union policies, and because his stores in small towns destroyed many small businesses.
column11: Sam Walton relied on his personality, hard work and a willingness to adopt new business practices to build Wal-Mart into the country's largest discount retailer. This made him the country's richest man, but he continued to live a simple life. Identification as the richest man made him uncomfortable. He was criticized for anti-union policies and causing the failure of small town businesses where he located his stores. Walton often visited his workers and kept them happy. Shortly before his death in 1992 Walton wrote a folksy autobiography. There is also a "scholarly study" on his business.
column12: Sam Walton died in April 1992, shortly after his 74th birthday on 29 March. He rose from humble beginnings to become the country's richest man.  He accomplished this by dint of hard work, an engaging personality and willingness to defy accepted retailing practices.After earning a college degree and serving in the army, he opened a Ben Franklin franchise in Arkansas. In 1962 his brother joined him and they opened the first Wal-Mart. When Wal-Mart was incorporated in 1971 there were 38 outlets. Wal-Mart's revenues then were only nine percent of Sears' and 11 percent of K-Mart's. Wal-Mart experienced phenomenal growth. In 1991, the year before Walton's death, Wal-Mart's revenues were greater than those of any other discount retailer. Walton eschewed the publicity that accompanied the annual Forbes' listing of the richest people. He spent most of his time at home in Arkansas, and whenever possible he visited his stores to exchange ideas with his salespeople, or as he called them "his associates".He was criticized for putting his stores in small towns, and causing the failure of many small businesses. He was also criticized for his anti-union policies.

column3: SQUADS workers fanned out storm-battered Louisiana yesterday tobegin massive rebuilding effort Hurricane Andrew had flattened wholedistricts, killing two people and injuring dozens more, agencies report fromFlorida and New Orleans.However, local officials Florida, hit earlier week thehurricane, were critical what they called delay supplying food,drinking water and other supplies thousands people need.Federal emergency officials acknowledged distribution problems,Transportation Secretary Andrew Card yesterday promised 'dramatic'improvements 24 hours and President George Bush last night orderedtroops Florida, specifying number.The government estimated it would cost Dollars 20bn-Dollars 30bn tidy andrebuild Florida, and care residents displaced storm.Louisiana state officials said they had no overall count storm-relatedinjuries initial estimates reckoned fewer 100. It has branch inOrlando.The company's loss adjusters are area trying estimate losses.Their guess is that losses be faced all insurers may total more thanDollars 8bn.Not all damaged property area is insured and there have beenestimates that storm caused more Dollars 20bn damage.However, other insurers have estimated that losses could be low asDollars 1bn total.Mr Robertson said: 'No one knows this time what exact loss is'.WHILE Hurricane Andrew was wreaking havoc large parts southernFlorida and Louisiana this week, grade two dollar crisis (on one-to-fourscale, four being most severe) was blowing itself out end atumultuous few days US and world financial markets.On Wall Street, most damage currency storm was inflicted aweek ago Friday and Monday, when bond yields jumped sharplyand Dow Jones industrial average plunged more 75 points.The flimsy walls erected hastily Federal Reserve and other bigcentral banks protect vulnerable dollar tidal wave sellingon foreign exchange markets failed hold; and sellers pouredthrough breached barricades, currency dropped DM1.40. The first is that it raises import prices and, result, adds toinflationary pressures.The second is that it makes it hard Fed engineer another cut ininterest rates stimulate flagging recovery, and raises thepossibility that rates may actually have go protect currency.The first explanation is not particularly convincing - imports account fornot much more 10 cent US gross domestic product, so higherimport prices do not greatly effect overall price level, which is nowaround 3 cent and heading lower.The second explanation carries more weight. Although there is not muchchance, given present economic and political climate, that Fed willraise rates help dollar, there is little doubt that currency'sweakness makes it extremely difficult Fed ease monetary policyagain.The fear that Fed may be done interest rate cuts presenteconomic cycle was also selling equity markets. But investorsin stocks were equally, if not more, troubled rise bond yields.Just week ago, yield benchmark 30-year bond, which hasremained stubbornly high all year poor state economy,looked if it might drop 7.3 cent.The dollar put paid those hopes and, middle this week, it wasapproaching 7.45 cent, putting upward pressure all-importantmortgage rate home-buyers.The dollar was not only story financial markets this week, and thedevastating effect Hurricane Andrew produced typically hard-eyed,although nonetheless logical, reaction Wall Street.The stocks those insurance companies greatest exposure insouthern Florida, area hit worst hurricane, all took tumble.But relatively modest losses Geico, Travelers and Progressivesuggested that market believed insurers were reserved or reinsuredadequately enough cover hurricane-related claims.The flip side hurricane's coin was strong showing stocksof home construction companies expected benefit demand forrebuilding damaged or destroyed homes. column5: Insurers face large claims from Hurricane Andrew's assault on the south.
column6: Hurricane Andrew caused about $20 billion damage.  About $8 billion is covered by insurance.  Most costs will fall on American companies, with British loses limited.  Andrew tore through southern Florida, flattening Homestead and leaving 25,000 homeless.  Industries and farms were damaged in Louisiana.  The dollar sustained a similar assault.
column7: Damage from Hurricane Andrew is estimated at $20 billion, with $8 billion covered by insurance.  American insurers will take the brunt of the claims, but General Accident, the leading British insurer, expects claims to rise as high as $40 million.  Andrew tore through southern Florida, leaving 15 dead, power outages, and polluted water in his wake.  Homestead and the nearby air force base were flattened.  In Dade County, 250,000 people are homeless.  Andrew next smashed into Louisiana, killing two.  It missed the important oil refineries, but damaged crops and the oyster and alligator businesses.  The dollar sustained a similar assault.
column8: Damage from Hurricane Andrew is estimated at $20 billion, with only $8 billion covered by insurance.  The last serious hurricane caused $4.2 billion in insured loses in 1989.  American insurers most affected by claims from Andrew are the State Farm Group, Allstate, Hartford Insurance, Aetna, and Travellers.  General Accident, the leading British insurer, expects their claims to rise as high as $40 million, which means the company may be able to pass losses on to external reinsurers.  Andrew hit the Bahamas, killing two, then on August 24 tore through southern Florida, where 15 were killed and power outages and polluted water plagued the residents for several days.  The city of Homestead and the nearby air force base were flattened.  In Dade County, 250,000 people are without homes.  After gathering strength over the Gulf of Mexico, Andrew next smashed into Louisiana, killing two and injuring dozens.  It did miss the important oil refineries, but damaged crops and the oyster and alligator businesses.  Andrew was downgraded to a tropical storm as it moved inland.While Andrew ravaged the land, the dollar sustained a similar assault.  Bond yields rose as the Dow Jones and the dollar fell.  Insurance stock also fell, but home construction stock had big gains.
column9: Hurricane Andrew, August 1992, Was Costliest to Date
column10: Hurricane Andrew hit the Bahamas, southern Florida and Louisiana in August 1992 killing 19 and causing extensive property damage, particularly in Florida. The cost to insurers was estimated as high as $20 billion. After a slow start federal assistance was dispatched to Florida and Louisiana. The cost of the Florida operation alone was estimated at $20-$30 billion.
column11: In August 1992 Hurricane Andrew hit the Bahamas, southern Florida, and Louisiana leaving 19 dead and extensive property damage. In Florida a quarter of a million were left homeless. The cost to insurers, concentrated in U.S. companies, was estimated as high as $20 billion and much of the damaged property was not insured. Federal authorities promised emergency aid after Florida officials complained of delays in supplying food and water. The cost of rebuilding Florida and caring for those displaced by the storm was estimated at $20-$30 billion. Fortunately the storm did not hit low-lying New Orleans or oil facilities along the gulf coast.
column12: Hurricane Andrew hit the Bahamas, southern Florida and Louisiana in August 1992 with winds ranging up to 165 miles per hour, killing 2 in the Bahamas, 15 in Florida, and 2 in Louisiana. The greatest property damage was in Florida where a quarter of a million people were left homeless and 2 million were without power. Property damage there exceeded $15 billion, most of it uninsured. An early estimate set the total cost of the storm to insurers at more than $8 billion, but others forecast a total as high as $20 billion, mainly to U.S. insurers. After local officials in Florida criticized delays in delivery of emergency supplies, the White House promised "dramatic" improvement within 24 hours and President Bush ordered troops to Florida. The U.S. government estimated it would cost $20 billion to $30 billion to rebuild Florida and care for those displaced by the storm. Fortunately Andrew did not hit low-lying New Orleans or off--shore oil facilities along the Gulf coast. After the hurricane had passed an article in the  "Financial Times" compared Andrew to a crisis in the value of the U.S. dollar which was "blowing itself out" during the course of the hurricane. The comparison was inept.

Thank you.Mr. Chairman, four my congressional colleagues and I are herefor purpose nominating next vice president UnitedStates.We are here nominate one bright young lights theRepublican Party, man I am proud say is my colleague, thejunior senator Indiana, Dan Quayle.You know, senators get lot mail. And now he is ready carrythat revolution forward.And believe me he is ready, and just let Democrats try touse experience measuring stick this campaign. Just let themtry.Now, I don't mean suggest their presidential candidate lacksexperience. He's got plenty experience, plenty experience experience raising taxes again and again, experience vetoingthe pledge allegiance public schools, experience inincreasing spending year year year Massachusetts.And I just don't believe American people want that kind ofexperience White House.It sounds Dukak-eyed idea me.But Dan Quayle's got experience, too. He's already spent 12years congressman and senator, tackling vital nationaland international issues that affect lives all Americans andthe future our country.That is 12 more years national experience MichaelDukakis  and he is running president.As I said start, Dan Quayle is man I know and trust. Dick Lugar.He is most important person ever come out this town, and asthe world considers his fitness presidency, Huntington is celebratinghis life what is ambitiously being billed Premiere Dan QuayleMemorabilia Exhibit.; To those who say Quayle does not merit his ownexhibition, Quayle devotees say mixture defiance and dignity that heis, all, vice president United States.; "We're preservinghistory," says David Schenkel, exhibition coordinator. column5: Indiana's Senator Quayle, Bush 1988 VP choice, attacked as novice
column6: Indiana Senator Dan Quayle, 41, George Bush's choice for vice-president in 1988, was criticized as a novice and his National Guard service and campaign gaffes attacked. Quayle briefly worked for state officials after college, and met and married his wife Marilyn in law school. They practiced law together before Quayle's 12 years in Congress.
column7: Indiana Senator Dan Quayle, 41, George Bush's surprise choice for vice-president in 1988, was criticized as a novice. His National Guard service and campaign gaffes were attacked. He proved a low-profile team player and Bush announced he would be on the 1992 ticket. Quayle's grandfather owned the newspaper in Quayle's hometown of Huntington. Quayle, known always as a nice guy, graduated from DePauw in 1969, took National Guard training, then in 1971 worked in the Indiana Attorney General's office and for the governor. At Indiana University Law School he met and married his wife Marilyn. They practiced law together before Quayle spent 12 years in Congress. They have three children.
column8: Indiana Senator Dan Quayle, 41, was the surprise choice of Republican George Bush for  presidential running mate in 1988. Quayle was compared to John F. Kennedy because of their similar ages and congressional service, and to Robert Redford in appearance. Quayle was criticized as a novice and his National Guard service attacked. His campaign gaffes made news, but he was loyal to Bush and a team player. After controversies subsided he kept a low profile. A year after the election he agreed to be on "Meet the Press", shortly after Bush announced he would be on the ticket in 1992, and was uncontroversial. Quayle grew up in Huntington, Indiana, population 17,000, where his grandfather owned the newspaper. He graduated from DePauw University in 1969, spent six months in National Guard training, then in 1971 investigated consumer problems in the Indiana Attorney General's office and became an aide to the governor. While attending Indiana University Law School he met and married his wife Marilyn. They jointly practiced law in Huntington before Quayle spent 12 years in the US Congress. Quayle has three children and is known as a nice guy with good values. In 1991, Huntington hosted an exhibit in his honor, which he didn't attend because of a busy schedule.
column9: Bush, friends support Quayle despite errors and political inexperience
column10: George Bush's selection of Dan Quayle as his running mate surprised many.Many political observers thought him a lightweight with baggage to carry.Bush continued to voice support for him even though Quayle was given only avery small role in the campaign and was not highly visible as vicepresident.
column11: George Bush's choice of Dan Quayle as his running mate surprised mostpolitical observers, but was quickly supported by many of Quayle's fellowRepublican senators. Quayle was viewed as a lightweight and questions wereraised about his military service and errors in his official resume. Hismain attributes were party loyalty and identification as a devoted familyman.  Quayle contributed little to the campaign and, after being elected,all but disappeared from the political scene.  President Bush, however,continued to voice support for, and confidence in Quayle.  His friends,especially in his home town, called him a winner.
column12: George Bush's choice of Indiana Senator Dan Quayle as his running mate,surprised most political observers.  Despite service in Congress andSenate, he was looked upon as lacking the experience and mettle for avigorous national campaign.  Several Republican senators rallied support.Senator John Warner of Virginia compared Quayle to Thomas Jefferson.Senator Bob Dole in nominating Quayle at the Republican Convention, calledhim a dedicated public servant and devoted family man and cited his supportfor the Reagan program.Devotion to family and friends was a theme voiced by those who had knownQuayle for many years. Relatives and friends believed that if Quayle wereelected, he and his family would remain a strong unit.Questions arose regarding Quayle's fitness for the job, and there were somesuggestions that he should withdraw.  He had called himself a "Vietnam-eraveteran" which angered some actual combat veterans.  Quayle's service was in the National Guard, a position he apparently gained through familyinfluence.  Quayle's resume contained a reference to a position held inIndiana, two years before it was created.Quayle survived these criticisms but did not play a strong role in thecampaign or as vice president.  Friends, especially those in his hometown,remained loyal.

column5: How Checkpoint Charlie Checked Out
column6: On June 22, 1990 Checkpoint Charlie, a symbol of the Cold War since 1961, was removed as part of an elaborate ceremony celebrating easing of east-west tension and the forthcoming unification of Germany. Top diplomats of the two Germanys and the four World War II allies took part in the festivities.
column7: On June 22, 1990 Checkpoint Charlie, the allied border crossing on the west side of the Berlin Wall, was hoisted by crane onto a flatbed truck. The removal of this symbol of the Cold War was part of an elaborate ceremony attended by the top diplomats of the two Germanys and the four World War II allies. Appropriate to the occasion, Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze backed away from all-out opposition to united Germany's membership in NATO, suggesting that this could take place but only after a five-year waiting period during which all Soviet and U.S. troops would leave thecountry.
column8: On June 22, 1990 Checkpoint Charlie, the allied border crossing on the west side of the Berlin Wall, was hoisted by a huge crane onto a flatbed truck to be taken to a museum. The guardhouse, constructed after erection of the Berlin Wall in 1961, was the scene of many successful and unsuccessful attempts at escape from East Berlin and had become a symbol of the Cold War. By June of 1990 with the Berlin Wall being dismantled daily in anticipation of German unification, and with top diplomats of the two Germanys and the four World War II allies meeting in East Berlin to discuss the status of the city after unification, U.S. officials decided it was time to remove the famous landmark. The foreign ministers attended an elaborate ceremony to honor the symbolic act. Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze took the occasion to modify the previous Soviet firm opposition to a united Germany's membership in NATO, proposing that such a step be allowed after a five-year waiting period during which all Soviet and U.S. troops would leave the country. U.S. Secretary of State Baker declared himself "underwhelmed" by the offer, but softening of the Soviet position was a welcome sign appropriate to the occasion.
column9: The Cold War ends as Checkpoint Charlie is lifted into history.
column10: As a U.S. army band played and the foreign ministers of the four World War II allies watched, Checkpoint Charlie, the symbol of the Cold War, was lifted into history today. Its removal came after East Germany overthrew its communist government and opened the border between the two Germanys.
column11: Checkpoint Charlie was lifted into history today during a ceremony including the foreign ministers of the four World War II allies. Secretary of State Baker, citing Checkpoint Charlie as a symbol of the Cold War, hoped its removal would bury the conflicts it created. Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze, the first Soviet foreign minister to visit Berlin, called for a removal of Berlin's status as an allied controlled city. Checkpoint Charlie became superfluous when the East Germany overthrew its communist-controlled government and the border between East and West Germany was opened. Although the ceremony was closed to the public, residents of the street watched from their windows.
column12: Checkpoint Charlie, the most famous symbol of the Cold War was lifted into history today. At an invitation only ceremony attended by the foreign ministers of the four World War II allies, a U.S. army band played an old Berlin song as the checkpoint was hoisted onto a waiting flatbed truck, to be taken to a museum. Speaking at the ceremony, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, the first Soviet foreign minister to visit Berlin, called for the removal of Berlin's status as an allied controlled city and the withdrawal of troops six months after the two German states unify. Secretary of State James Baker, citing Checkpoint Charlie's status as a Cold War symbol, expressed the hope that its removal would bury the conflicts it created. The decision to remove Checkpoint Charlie came as large sections of the wall were being dismantled and the opening of the border between the two Berlins made the checkpoint superfluous. Its removal was timed to coincide with a meeting of German and Allied foreign ministers in East Berlin to discuss the status of Berlin and a united Germany. Among the invited guests was West Germany's Chancellor Willy Brandt who was mayor of Berlin in the 1960s.
